Anyways, The Catcher in the Rye takes the crown as my favorite book solely because my heart feels funny whenever I think about it, I own a red hunting hat, and sometimes I think about Holden Caulfield and feel my emotional stability absolutely crumble so thanks for that, Jerome.

I read this as a teenager in high school, and then just recently for my book club. The Catcher in the Rye and To Kill a Mockingbird influenced my thinking for years to come. I was forever attracted to books that dealt with real human situations and emotions. Holden Caulfield was a "lost boy" - disillusioned by his status-conscious world. Everything was "phony" and money could only buy temporary happiness. Adolescence is a painful time for most of us: life seems so complex and unmanageable at that age. Emotions run so very high. I absolutely identified with all of Holden's fears and discontent the first time I read this book. Lately, I have been reading quite a few Young Adult novels because many of the Contemporary and New Adult novels seem to be focused on fabulously wealthy CEOs and or the successful JOCKS. Give me instead a story with realistic characters, enduring and overcoming present day conflicts, and add a dash of hope and positivity, and I'm all in!

I read this about 50 years ago and a couple of times since. It speaks to the most inner parts of a teenager as it tries to make you more normal with the unreal challenge of growing up and more knowledgeable and mature.You just have to listen and learn.repeat every 10 years. Pass it to your kids and give them a hug. They will remember you for that. Be there if needed and always be truthful. Admit you were not perfect. Laugh at your stupid mistakes and teach them that life is worth living no matter how bad they think it is. It will get better.
The book is magical. It has left an indelible mark.

This is another of those books I should have read as a teenager, but never got round to. I hope my teenage self would have been just as irritated by it as I was. However I recognise feelings about this are mixed and friends on here seem to love and hate it equally. It’s been one of the most regularly banned books in US schools for its language and “adult themes” and at one point for being part of a communist plot!The plot and themes are well known; but it’s the voice of Holden Caulfield that marks out the book. The narrow timescale and scope put a heavy burden on the character of Holden, which for me the character couldn’t carry. He starts and ends the book as an irritating, self absorbed and whining brat and there appears to be little development and spending the whole book inside his head is a painful experience.I need to move onto something entirely different.

You can find my review on my blog by clicking here.Everyone is a goddamn phony. It’s almost impossible to finish this book without having that sentence engraved in your thoughts, forever. The Catcher in the Rye was one of my most surprising reading experiences yet. It’s not your conventional young adult story. It is a book that has known censorship before embracing immense fame. It’s popularity grew at an exponential speed and ended up getting incredible praise among teenagers. How? It was all in Holden Caufield, the protagonist of The Catcher in the Rye, and how so many adolescents were able to relate with him. This story is a glimpse into the life of Holden Caufield. He narrates the events, one after the other, and puts forth his entire thought process in black and white. After learning that he once again got kicked out of high school, Holden Caufield decides to follow his gut feeling and takes a trip to New York City. Through these events, readers uncover a child who’s simply falling into adulthood. In this story marinating in a theme of coming of age, Holden Caufield is an elegy for adolescents. It’s through his confusion, his angst, his pain, his pleasures and his desires that we see his struggle to remain a child, yet swimming in a world of adults.As I was reading, I thought I was going to end up hating this book. Everything about it seemed to be paving the way for the hate to roar out of me. There’s no exposition, there’s no climax, there’s no denouement and there’s no ending. The whole book is a sequence of actions told through the voice of Holden Caufield and his particular writing style. His hypocritical behavior, his cynicism, his repetitive language, his sarcasm, his swearing and his ability to digress are all there to strain you and build your patience for this character. You wouldn’t believe me if I told you the number of times he might have gotten on my nerves. Just his abusive use of “that killed me” would give me a brain aneurysm. Although it was somehow compelling to read about Caufield’s thoughts on a person or on a thing in particular, you always felt like he wasn’t leading you anywhere. His ability to digress is absolutely stunning. He could see a person at a bar and end up bringing you on a journey through memory lane. It’s only after finishing The Catcher in the Rye that it hit me. I actually did enjoy this. I actually did appreciate the thoughts of Holden Caufield and the way J.D. Salinger delivered this cynical child’s story. I actually did understand what Holden Caufield was going through. I felt like I had told parts of my own childhood to him and fell in this trap of getting attached to him. In the end, Holden Caufield was right. “Don’t ever tell anybody anything. If you do, you start missing everybody.”Holden Caufield is without a doubt the biggest phony out there. But why he is such a person is where things become so much more interesting. There isn’t a moment throughout the book that you won’t see him pointing fingers to every phony out there. Even in today’s society, there’s no denying the number of people who put on a farce and pretend to be someone they’re not or say things that they don’t honestly believe in. Even if Holden Caufield is able to see through these people, making it even more obvious that his adulthood is catching up to him, he does the exact same thing throughout the book. In fact, he blatantly admits to being one of the biggest liars out there. But it’s this irony and this contradiction that makes his adolescent self so intriguing. The way he perceives life brings him to alienate himself from the world and not bother with people who can’t stay true to themselves. In fact, I found that Holden is a strong believer of talking from the heart, of saying things that bring your excitement and leaves you in a peaceful trance. But what he believes and what he does are two completely different things, since he too has difficulties expressing himself or even a disinterest to do so. Holden Caufield is a very complex character who’s easily seen by many readers as a rebel who doesn’t want to do things that he doesn’t feel like doing. His desire to live in the present and to do things that simply pop into his mind makes his adventures so spontaneous.It’s heartwarming to see Holden Caufield want to preserve the childhood of every kid out there. Without explicitly saying so, you can tell from his behaviors and beliefs that it is something very important for him, especially when he’s starting to realize that he had already fallen off the cliff. His wish to be that person to stop others from falling off the cliff into adulthood is something that can easily strike a chord among readers. Even if Holden Caufield remains the biggest phony in this story, he somehow managed to make me like the guy. The Catcher in the Rye has been a controversial novel that has managed to join the list of banned books in history. It’s depiction of a cynical teenager who tackles themes of sexuality, drinking, profanity and many other things has made this a book that could stir the morals and values of a lot of individuals. Just to make it even more shocking, I’ve read that this book has even made the headlines alongside killers. The biggest story related to The Catcher in the Rye is the death of John Lennon. Mark David Chapman, the infamous killer who took Lennon’s life, was arrested with a copy of this book bought on the same day he killed him. Inside the book he left this note: “To Holden Caufield, From Holden Caufield. This is my statement.” Now, is being able to relate to the character a good or bad thing? I’ll let you find out.Yours truly,Lashaan | Blogger and Book ReviewerOfficial blog: http://bookidote.wordpress.com____________________________Everyone is a goddamn phony. It's almost impossible to finish this book without having that sentence engraved in your thoughts, forever. This book was one of the most surprising reading experiences yet. As I was reading, I thought I was going to end up hating it. Everything seemed to be paving the way for the hate. There's no climax, there's no denouement, there's no ending whatsoever. There is a cynical teenager who narrates the events of a couple days after being kicked out for the billionth time from high school. His hypocritical behavior, his cynicism, his repetitive language, his sarcasm, his swearing and his ability to digress are all there to strain you and build your patience for this character. The whole book is a collection of events seen through the eyes of Holden Caufield. It's only after finishing The Catcher in the Rye that it hit me. I actually did enjoy this. I actually did appreciate the thoughts of the character and the way J.D. Salinger delivered his story. I actually did understand what Holden Caufield was going through.Holden Caufield is without a doubt the biggest phony out there. But why he is such a person is where things become so much more interesting.P.S. Full review to come soonYours truly,Lashaan | Blogger and Book ReviewerOfficial blog: http://bookidote.wordpress.com

This book made me extremely irritable. The only thing that would have made it enjoyable was if the protagonist were a real person whom I could slap repeatedly. However, compared to much recent lit I have to at least give Salinger credit for good grammar and competent writing.

I read this years ago for the first time and many times since. It's one of my all time favorite classics. Salinger is one of those rare authors who make you feel as though he is quietly relating his story directly to you.
BEST. COMING-OF-AGE. STORY. EVER. It's a classic for a reason. Thank you, J.D. Salinger for writing a masterpiece. Unforgettable, haunting, and relatable.

1.5Well, I first heard The Catcher in the Rye when I was in first year college and my cousin was listening to the song We Didn't Start the Fire since he will use it for a project or a presentation if I'm not mistaken. After that, I've searched what is it and found out that it was a book but I'm not fond of reading novels way back that time so I didn't search what it was all about. I just have the idea that it was a book.Then after a long, long years, I finally read it and boy, was i get disappointed. Boy, was I get annoyed. Holden was annoying as fuck. I tried to understand him and symphatize with him and boy I can't. I don't know but I really can't. I also tried to think deep and dig my emotions about what I learned from this book or what I felt about the characters and the story itself and I think I've got none and none, just a couple of boy-sentences and annoyance, probably. And in this kind of book that seems plotless or doesn't have a compelling plot, I'm rooting from the main character to what will he become or to what I will learn from him or from the story itself or what I will realize after all but yeah, none.Anyway, I liked a particular scene and that includes Phoebe or probably I just like Phoebe thus I liked that particular scene. I enjoyed her character so the 1.5 stars solely goes to her.Goodbye.

JESUS WEPT.Now I know why a movie has never been made of The Catcher in the Rye - because even Zac Efron wouldn't want to be in it. The reason I've given this book one star is because Goodreads have yet to develop the Negative Ratings system, but I'm sure they'll catch up soon.This is a 'seminal classic', or so every hipster worth his bicycle basket would have you believe. So when I finally got around to reading it as a 36 year old mother of 4, I was thrilled to be finding out what all the fuss is about. All I can say is, thank God I've read it for the first time at an age where I can articulate my emotions, because if I had read it in high school, I'm pretty sure the entire world would have be reduced to pink mist at the frustrated and disgruntled hands of my AK-47.It slices me in half that this drivel is so lauded when there are kindergarten kids writing perfectly good sentences about whales and bananas which never make it out of the classroom, much less onto a 100-books-to-read-before-you-die list. There were a couple of astute observations, and there are several passages that are quite amusing, but the problem is that by the time you get to them, you are so atrophied with boredom that your body no longer remembers how to laugh and can only emit a slow, pained whine instead. Or maybe that was just Holden, moaning again?There is absolutely nothing this character does not complain about. I'm pretty sure that if a clown tried to give him a balloon filled with 40 million dollars, Holden would call him a phoney and tell him to fuck off. Are we supposed to be surprised that he's actually a virgin? Of course he is. Imagine him having sex with someone - "My orgasm was pretty crummy. How was yours goddammit. Wait...you didn't have one? ARE YOU A PHONEY? Boy, that kills me, if you want to know the truth. I mean. Boy."No wonder JD Salinger became a recluse after this became so successful. I'd be embarrassed too.

My graduate degrees in English must be worthless. I just didn't see a point to it at all. Boy gets kicked out of school, thinks about things, meets up with a prostitute, thinks about things some more, winds up inexplicably optimistic. Weird.A friend of mine commented that I'm not angst-y enough to appreciate this book. Probably true.Holden might not be the everyteen that he used to be.Here is an appropriate Chesterton quotation, and this comment on a Goodreads review rang true: "It's despairing young teenagers who are too smart and spoiled for their own good, complaining about the human condition and never actually coming to a meaningful moral worldview."Read sometime around 2008.

Extremely humorous. I often found myself laughing out loud while reading the book, and extremely insightful The lead character makes some very insightful observations about the shallowness of adolescent social life I loved it and couldn't put it down A book anyone anyone who has experienced a difficult adolescence can relate to-even looking back thirty years after my teens have passed And what's more-its hard to believe this book was written 70 years ago

Update (7/28/21): some people are being super nice to me about my Catcher in the Rye review, so I decided to spruce it up with some quotes. The review has been slightly tweaked for analysis - I expanded on a few of my thoughts, but it's mostly the same. Also, I'm 25 now. Gross.REVIEW 2 at 23 years old (2019): 
“Among other things, you’ll find that you’re not the first person who was ever confused and frightened and even sickened by human behavior. You’re by no means alone on that score, you’ll be excited and stimulated to know. Many, many men have been just as troubled morally and spiritually as you are right now. Happily, some of them kept records of their troubles. You’ll learn from them—if you want to. Just as someday, if you have something to offer, someone will learn something from you. It’s a beautiful reciprocal arrangement. And it isn’t education. It’s history. It’s poetry.”
The thing about The Catcher in the Rye is that if you don't feel as though you can relate to Holden, then he is going to be too annoying for you to enjoy the novel. He sure annoys the hell out of me, but I actually feel for the kid.
“I can be quite sarcastic when I’m in the mood.”
I can 100% understand someone not enjoying this. The EXTREME stream of consciousness writing is almost too much to deal with at times. Holden is also the most redundant literary character I have ever met. There are some pretty offensive comments made throughout the book. Yeah, it's definitely within your rights to toss this one to the side - but I beg you to give it a chance. CW: sexual abuse, child death:I think Holden was sexually abused. I also think Jane was sexually abused. See, Holden thinks that sexual acts are in and of themselves "crumby" (aka rude/disrespectful) things to do to someone. Since Holden associates anything sex related with being disrespectful, he can't reconcile with the fact that when he genuinely likes someone he would also do sexual things with them - why would you disrespect someone you care about? 
“Life is a game, boy. Life is a game that one plays according to the rules.""Yes, sir. I know it is. I know it."Game, my ass. Some game. If you get on the side where all the hot-shots are, then it's a game, all right-I'll admit that. But if you get on the other side, where there aren't any hot-shots, then what's a game about it? Nothing. No game.
Holden also has this "issue" with not being able to see women as sex objects. It's weird, right? It feels offensive the way he speaks about women, but at the end of the day it's because he sees them as living, breathing human beings with personalities and quirks instead of just something to have sex with. He is surrounded by people, particularly Stradlater, who seems to take advantage of women all the time. Holden can't bring himself to do it. He knows what it's like to be taken advantage of, to be treated in a "crumby" way. Whenever he and Jane are together, they are clearly enjoying the companionship and emotional support aspect of relationships more so than the sexual parts. It's important to note, this goes for both of them because they are both victims. 
“This fall I think you're riding for—it's a special kind of fall, a horrible kind. The man falling isn't permitted to feel or hear himself hit bottom. He just keeps falling and falling. The whole arrangement's designed for men who, at some time or other in their lives, were looking for something their own environment couldn't supply them with. Or they thought their own environment couldn't supply them with. So they gave up looking. They gave it up before they ever really even got started.”
Maybe the molestation wasn't taken to extreme circumstances, but I do think Holden has been made to feel uncomfortable around adults in a sexual manner. This is why he has such a hard time performing sexually like other guys his age. This is also an explanation for his hatred of the phrase "fuck you" written as graffiti all over the place. 
"That’s the whole trouble. You can’t ever find a place that’s nice and peaceful, because there isn’t any. You may think there is, but once you get there, when you’re not looking, somebody’ll sneak up and write 'Fuck you' right under your nose."
Holden is 
obscenely
 vulgar, yet he cannot stand to see that phrase written on a wall. He hates the idea that someone, particularly young children, will see it and be ruined by it. I think this connects to his possible sexual abuse because "fuck" can be sexually explicit, and Holden's vulgarity tends to stay away from obscene sexual phrases. (This analysis could totally be wrong, of course, since this novel is pretty old and language changes all the time.) It's also pretty significant that the ONE adult that Holden gets good advice from - advice that Holden does not criticize (for once), advice that seems genuine - is someone who can definitely be considered a predator. Salinger might be touching on the fact that nothing is ever 100% innocent, a theme that is prevalent throughout the novel. It just really sucked to see Holden so creeped out and scared. Especially by someone he thought he could trust. Not only was he abused, but he also had to deal with the death of his little brother, Allie. 
“My brother Allie had this left-handed fielder’s mitt. He was left handed. The thing that was descriptive about it though, was that he had poems written all over the fingers and the pocket and everywhere. In green ink. He wrote them on it so that he’d have something to read when he was in the field and nobody was up to bat. He’s dead now.”
The first death children typically experience is a grandparent. A sibling is a far more unexpected, probably more painful loss. To realize what death is at such a young age, and to have it happen to his innocent brother is an extreme blow to Holden's development.
“I know he's dead! Don't you think I know that? I can still like him, though, can't I? Just because somebody's dead, you don't just stop liking them, for God's sake — especially if they were about a thousand times nicer than the people you know that're alive and all.”
Allie's death definitely gives Holden some form of post traumatic stress. It's important to acknowledge how much Holden loves his younger sister, Phoebe. His love and admiration for her throughout the book is probably exactly how he felt about Allie. It's also indicative of how he views most children.
“When you're dead, they really fix you up. I hope to hell when I do die somebody has sense enough to just dump me in the river or something. Anything except sticking me in a goddam cemetery. People coming and putting a bunch of flowers on your stomach on Sunday, and all that crap. Who wants flowers when you're dead? Nobody.”
Overall, this book is about a teenage boy who really, really, really does not want to let go of innocence, and it's too late for him, but maybe not for the kids around him. Holden wants children to stay pure (and alive). Holden wants there to truly be a selfless good deed. Holden wishes people were more genuine (hatred of movies = hatred of actors = hatred of people being "phonies"). Holden just wants to catch all the kids in the rye!! Let him catch the kids, damnit! 
“Anyway, I keep picturing all these little kids playing some game in this big field of rye and all. Thousands of little kids, and nobody’s around – nobody big, I mean – except me. And I’m standing on the edge of some crazy cliff. What I have to do, I have to catch everybody if they start to go over the cliff – I mean if they’re running and they don’t look where they’re going I have to come out from somewhere and catch them. That’s all I do all day. I’d just be the catcher in the rye and all. I know it’s crazy, but that’s the only thing I’d really like to be."
There's many layers to this book to analyze, including that this is a post WWII novel. I won't get into that because this is long enough, but it's worth noting that Allie died of Leukemia, which a lot of survivors of the atom bomb ended up developing. Holden is a teenager in a postwar society and all Holden can see is the fact that humanity is kind of garbage, and he wants nothing to do with it.It's also possible that Holden is gay and can't come to terms with it. Yet another thing you could analyze in depth. 
“I’m just going through a phase right now. Everybody goes through phases and all, don’t they?”
Also, for a "socially inept" kid, Holden has quite an insightful mind and a high emotional intelligence. He's very observant and considerate. He gets taken advantage of a lot and doesn't seem to realize it consciously, which is probably why he's reluctant to interact with people - he seems to always somehow get screwed over. Just some more things to think about.
"I’m always saying 'Glad to’ve met you' to somebody I’m not at all glad I met. If you want to stay alive, you have to say that stuff, though."
This book is definitely a classic for a reason. Hate it all you want, but teenagers that can relate to Holden definitely need books like this. I can say with certainty that this book makes me feel less alone in a world where everything kind of sucks all the time. 
“I like it when somebody gets excited about something. It’s nice.”
REVIEW 1 at 18 years old: Love this book.

“If you had a million years to do it in, you couldn't rub out even half the "Fuck you" signs in the world. It's impossible.” ― J.D. Salinger, The Catcher in the RyeI am way to tired to do a long review on this book but I had it in my "read" pile and it has come up in conversation lately so I figured I'd write a few lines. I know so many think it is way overrated. I feel that way about many classics. I could not even make it through "Lolita" without skimming so..I agree there is always going to be that one classic..or two or three..that one simply cannot connect to.This one wasn't it for me. I have to give it five stars because I was but a little slip of a girl, just finding my way in the reading world. This book was an influence on me. I liked Holden, I felt for him..and he made me laugh. And I can remember some down times when, his sarcasm and snarky sense of humor would just prop be right back up.I have not read this multiple times or anything. Actually I have not read it in years. I do not even know if I'd like it now. But back then I thought it was great and special and different. I devoured the book. And count it as a major influence in my reading.So for me..it's a five. Perhaps some day I'll reconnect with Holden. We will see.

This is not a book which speaks universally, but to those ‘The Catcher in the Rye’ does reach - primarily males - it strikes them like lightening. Or so I've noticed.Holden does not speak to me. Every time I read this I want to throw the book across the room and stomp around and slap every man stupid. In the end, I like Holden, because he decides to examine his sorrows and losses to a minimal degree, but he annoys the crap out of me through most of the book. This famous novel is definitely not a girl's coming of age story (women when young share feelings, generally, even if only to a doll or a journal and know, mostly, why we feel mean or crappy eventually. We're made to feel like those feelings shouldn't be felt, too, but I think generally girls KNOW exactly what they are feeling.) Some of Holden's misdirected rage reminds me of how real men still handle issues today - which pretty much sucks just like Holden's methodology. While the author's skill is tremendous in defining the internal trauma of a 1950's-era boy unable to process his pain, the self-destructive blown-up wretchedness makes me angry at Holden for his stupidity and self-involvement. Why can't he, and others of his sex, fricking reach out and honestly talk about his pain? Why do most other boys spit in his face because he's miserable? Why do many grown-up males give the kind of advice to suffering males designed to create abusers, bullies and serial killers, even now? Like, "Man up" "Suck it up" "What are you, a girl (creating a future wife-beater, thanks ever so much...)" "Crybaby (do we not all have tear ducts?)"  I'M SCrEaMinG NOW!Teen girls should read this so they can identify some of the ways some males behave, which is beyond rationality and destructive. Girls,  YOU CAN'T FIX THEM.  For many men, they maintain a case of meanness and grudge forever for everyone they meet in life because they never come out of it or learn communication or examine their internal pain. Holden's agonies and his attempt at burying the pain as deeply down as he can ring absolutely true about many males. The lack of support he receives from many also rings true. In this kind of trouble, generally speaking, a boy needs a man's help. But it has to be a man who has examined his own life, and can talk about it. A grown-up mentor needs to be a regular guy-type, plays basketball or something, goes fishing, stuff like that, too. Stereotypical and absolutely true. I'm serious. It's like that. Sigh. I recognize some guys also knit and grow flowers and like to dress up, but many young boys are scared by individuality - it's part of their young boy pack mentality stage to kill the different.In the 1950s, especially, American society was very repressed and bent by the emotional suppression of negativity and bodily functions or dirt (I mean real earth dirt and dust) or any recognition of death, dying, or child/female abuse, old clothes, and nonconformity of any kind which strayed from a twin-bed married life. The majority of American people were carrying Holden's confusions within themselves. Any wild or real expressions of emotion were socially condemned unless released in controlled and restrained manners. Drinking a fifth every night was ok, though.I  HATED the 1950's in good ol' USA.

Welcome (back) to the realm of teenage, where you are sensitive, bored and full of nonsense. Here's where you think you are like no other, that the world is full of fools and you probably weren't meant to live in this era." If a body meet(s) a body coming through the rye...", a song the main character likes but plays around around with the lyrics .This is one of the few novels that I enjoyed mainly due to the way the narrator speaks. The way he speaks is the way he writes, so it's not only dialogues that are full of teenage angst.There's almost nothing significant happening around, yet A LOT is happening in the mind of this sixteen your old boy who's just been expelled from school. He's not talented, he's not popular but you've got to love the way he criticizes the world and its people with all their folly, pretension and shallowness."Where do all the ducks in the lake go when it's winter and the lake is frozen?", a qustion Holden kept asking grown ups, to no avail.Holden Caulfield is an icon of troubled teenage. The one who strikes you as spontaneous and even rash, but on the other side, he is passionate and funny. He ought to remind you of yourself if ,some time ago, you were a confused, angry teenager.

Really good book! It's nice and refreshing to read about a male character and his thoughts towards issues other than girls.Initial Thought:1. Holden kills me. I thought he was entertaining, funny, and very angsty. I found it really interesting reading about a male's perspective on issues regarding people and their behavior.2. Lot's of swearing! Didn't bother me, but it did feel overused.3. Although the plot is not a straightforward storyline, the events that took place were interesting, and at some points entertaining. It was difficult to tell where the story was going.4. I really enjoyed the ending, and the thoughts/themes presented throughout the book.You can check out my video review here!

This is one of those books that they made you read in high school and you briefly felt a feeling of catharsis reading it before it disappeared from your consciousness until mid-life when you read it again. At least, that was what this was like for me. Holden is the rebel without a cause (perhaps without a clue as well) and his adventures after being kicked out of yet another high school are Rabelesque and funny with a twinge of morosity. It is hardly an optimistic book and has an ambiguous ending. However, it lays such a unique groove and has had such a massive cultural influence that it deserves a 5* rating. It is a pleasure to read, but the conclusions you draw will be uniquely your own.

Look, I know what you're thinking. This novel is a flat line. It doesn't even have a decent climax. And it's just about a sarcastic kid who's angry at anything he crosses paths with. But I'll tell you this, everyone who had a normal angst-y adolescence would know what this did. Justice. Holden boy was the exact replica of an adolescent kid, his thoughts were what we experienced when we were his age and I still experience it. It's like listening to yourself, or is it just me? This is the quintessence of those ruddy years when we were filled with hormones and hate.

"God, I wish you could've been there." I enjoyed the hell out this reread. I didn't write a review when I first read this about 6-7 years ago and I'm not going to now. We all know it's polarizing. You either identify with Caulfield or you don't. I have a son named Holden so I think you know where I stand. ☺️
Strongly recommended, one of the best ✋

Reread February 2018: Yep, I'm still emo.4 1/2 stars - RTC***
April 2017 Review
Is anyone surprised that the one classic I really enjoyed ended up being the one everyone complains about being angsty and emo? Yeah, me neither.This is the book my history teacher described as the quintessential book of the 1950’s. I remarked that we were reading it in English currently. My history teacher laughed and asked how many of us already wanted to slap Holden by page 10. Many of the kids laughed and eagerly nodded along.I was probably the only one who was never once tempted to slap Holden, or to tell him to just grow up, or yell at him to get his shit together. To be honest, I kinda wanted to give the guy a hug.Holden Caulfield is a 16 year old boy, and like many of us at 16, he is struggling immensely with the fact that he is growing up. Coping (well, actually not coping at all) with the loss of his brother and continually being kicked out of schools for poor grades, Holden takes off for a few days in New York City rather than heading home and having to face the disappointment of his parents yet again.This book surprised me so much. I could see how much thought was put into the story. I mean, it’s so symbolic. When one of our essay options was to write an entire essay just on Holden’s hat, you know this book has depth. I went back and found some insane foreshadowing as well. It has so many opportunities to create brilliant discussions between readers.I think the story has a unique character voice and Holden is incredibly developed and complex. He’s not a perfect person; he’s judgemental, impulsive, and can be horrible to those around him.But, to be honest, I saw myself a bit in Holden. Okay, a lot. Occasionally I did stop and think to myself please tell me I don’t sound like this. Holden struggles so much to perceive the world around him, realizing as he grows up just how dark it can be. Maybe it’s because Holden and I are at similar ages, finding our places in the world.I just loved the overall tone of this story, which could be funny but also had this somber undertone that made the story seem beautiful beyond its crude language and angry narrator. It was those sad little passages that reflected the complexity of life that made me fall in love with this story.I also am kind of astonished that there was a mental health themed story out at this time. Holden, no doubt, is suffering from depression. I love mental health novels, so that was just an added bonus.This book is a character study at its best. Plot? Nah. This book is just about Holden running around New York, not really doing anything, but that’s completely fine by me. Some of the best stories just explore life without much happening.That reminds me; this book reminds me so much of one of my all time favorite novels, The Spectacular Now. Honestly, so similar; both coming of age character studies about a spiraling teenage boy. Love both of them, so if you love one I imagine you’ll at least enjoy the other.Also, is this technically the first YA book? I’ve heard that title go to The Outsiders many times, but this book is 30 years older and most definitely YA if you ask me.Anyway, I’m really glad I read this book. I love Holden so much that I had a hard time in class not taking personal offense after anyone in class insulted him lol. Try not to be turned off by the first few pages. If you look for it, there is so much beauty in this story.

It's strange, but I agree with the tagline of this novel for once. Usually it's just there for dramatic effect. "You'll never forget this story, this story will haunt you for life....,etc", but this one actually has proven true. I read this months ago and now that I'm adding the reviews to the blog from Goodreads and my mental reservoir, I have to say that this book truly has never left me. I think of it at least once every two weeks. I have no idea why really, but I think there's such a total genuineness about it that it really gets inside you.The book isn't perfect because of the bizarre writing style, which would turn some off. I know some don't even keep going. You should push through any awkward growing pains, though, as it did prove to be so rewarding. The main character of Holden Caulfield is hard to get into at first, since he initially seems to be a smart-alek, dirty-mouthed, negative kid who doesn't care about much. It becomes clear after awhile he's troubled, lonely, compassionate, and actually a sweetheart.You end up feeling for him, caring about what happens, and trying to figure out how he can turn himself around, or if he even wants to and has reason enough to try. He is certainly not the typical character to read about, and this type of character is another reason I feel reading fiction encourages the growth of empathy in people so much.The scene that really stands out to me is the sadness of the hotel room scenario between Holden, the girl, and her pimp. How tragic and I felt for him as his youth really came through.It's a completely character-orientated novel. There's a strange opening to the book where not much is going on, and little ever happens action-wise. It's mainly an introverted thinking novel. You don't get the sense that the boy is troubled until a few chapters in, other than he's failing out of school. I would have liked a longer ending also, to see his parents reactions and more details of what happened next.Overall this is a worthy classic - I felt for the character and thought it held interesting insight. Language is pretty graphic so some parents may not want their kids reading it if too young. There's no sex or anything violent, although their are several adult implications. For the life of me I can't understand some of the blame from criminals on this book - the person is troubled, fragile, and lonely, but they are not violent, twisted, or evil.I rated this four stars after I read it because of some of the overly long paragraphs and ramblings got a bit much sometimes, and I would have enjoyed a little more action and thought editing slightly would have helped. However, if I rated it now from memory alone would have went for the big 5-star label. It's just one of those books that truly stays with you.

“Among other things, you'll find that you're not the first person who was ever confused and frightened and even sickened by human behavior. You're by no means alone on that score, you'll be excited and stimulated to know. Many, many men have been just as troubled morally and spiritually as you are right now. Happily, some of them kept records of their troubles. You'll learn from them—if you want to. Just as someday, if you have something to offer, someone will learn something from you. It's a beautiful reciprocal arrangement. And it isn't education. It's history. It's poetry.”First of all, this book contains some wonderful quotes, I won't deny."Don't ever tell anybody anything. If you do, you start missing everybody."Phew...I don't seem to have any grudges for Holden, in fact, I feel bad for him. I can understand all that teenage angst and how it feels like to be around phony people; makes me remember my own 16-years-old self and how it would have loved reading this book back then, would have been glad to have a best friend like Holden. ( Also, the usage of word "phony" made me goddamn annoyed, just like that. )To be honest, I don't really know how I feel about this book. I didn't get the message or the purpose it's trying to convey, the whole era, NYC back then, it made it hard for me to relate with certain things despite finding similarities with Holden.I have seen everyone talking so much about Holden but barely speaking anything about Phoebe. I mean every character named Phoebe is just so sweet.I literally adored that smart little child, she's just so kind, and not only as a supportive sister to her brother but as a person in whole. I think we need to learn those bits from her, it makes her a beautiful human being.I don't actually like reading depressing books, but if you do, you can read this classic! Maybe you'll end up loving it.

I did not like to read this book at all. Born and brought up in India, I think we as teenagers are very different from the rest of the world. In my teenager years, we were obsessed with doing well in exams. We didn't have time to think about our crushes. That was our life and our life was good. we had problems of course, but we had learned not to make fuss about anything except studies. We were not brooding.I get what it means to be a teenager. When you think nobody understands you or nobody feels what your are going through But this Holden himself was an annoying, whiny and irritating character. From start to the end he was lonesome and depressed and things either killed him or annoyed him or were just plain pathetic according to him. Wake up, boy. This is life, that's how it is. It's nothing special what you are going through. Everyone goes through that and it's not even suffering what you feel.I kept on reading because I wanted someone to twist his ear and give him some good old scolding to grow up but in the end I was disappointed as nothing of that sort happened.I get the slang and everything, I have read clockwork Orange for God's sake which is like classic example of slangs. But this one did not give me even an ounce of literary pleasure.Only thing I liked was holden was caring to his brother Allie and his sister Phoebe and he admired and cared for them for being good. 2 stars only for not being a douchebag to them!!

The Catcher in the rye , J.D Salinger's first published novel , is one of the novels that you either love or hate , there is no in between .The story revolves around Holden Caufield ,16 years old and a native new yorker , as we dive into his depression and strange behaviours , while he's narrating his own story .At first , it was weird and quite disturbing . You're positive that something is wrong with him but you can't tell what was it , Holden was mysterious and odd , at the same time .The style of writing is provocative ( Holden's experiences with girls , the way he's treating others , his ' superiority issues' , his indifference towards others) , but intriguing and very addictive.Even though a lot of people hated Holden , I didn't ! I ended up loving him for his honesty , his love for his sister , but most importantly , his kind heart ( yet sick mind lol) .The Catcher in the rye touches on a lot of issues such as life problems , friendships , ambitions , future , family .. yet , they remain unanswered.This book is simply weird , but definitely WORTH IT.

"Boy, when you're dead, they really fix you up. I hope to hell when I do die somebody has sense enough to just dump me in the river or something... People coming and putting a bunch of flowers on your stomach on Sunday, and all that crap. Who wants flowers when you're dead? Nobody."I picked this book up and couldn't put it down. Holden Caulfield is whiny, egotistical, and arrogant, but he's also disillusioned and tired of the superficial life he lives. I think everyone comes at a point in their lives where they want to run away, make a new life where nobody knows them and not be stuck in a compartmentalized version of themselves. Add this angsty teenage phase and a mental breakdown and you get Holden. He annoyed me at points because of his instantaneous negative reactions to damn near everything and everyone, but he is clearly enduring mental turmoil at this stage of his life.I think the novel does a masterful job at showing what many teenagers go through and how quickly their minds and the course of their life change.

i don't know why but i cried, like, three times. holdon is such a strange character to read from but you could clearly see that he's an extremely complex and thorough characters. this book made me think and think and think. i haven't read one that's given me that type of experience for a while so it was really refreshing. i love this not because the writing was good or plot was or even characters were good; i love this this because it is so in-depth and the layers in the meaning are endless. symbols! metaphors!
The thing with kids is, if they want to grab for the gold ring, you have to let them do it, and not say anything. If they fall off, they fall off, but it's bad if you say anything to them.
This book is like home to the devastated: you keep coming back to it because of the pain. So pure, so frail, so beautiful.

Oh I really love this book, I really do. I mean it. I do love this book with all my heart. Sorry I turned into Holden Caulfield all of a sudden. But honestly this book was such a blast and very engaging to read. It is definitely my favorite "classic" read of all time. It was unexpectedly funny and I definitely found myself laughing out loud in major moments. His jokes are categorized as “black humor” which is one of my favorite types of humor. J.D. Singler perfectly writes this book as if it’s coming from a sixteen year old boy. It’s as if Holdens stream of consciousness was let out in this book. Every single detail and idea that came up on his read was written out. I personally found it to be extremely accurate based on a young adults perspective. One of my favorite aspects of this novel is the explicit vs implicit narrative, in other words, the writers common phrase of “show but don’t tell”, leaving it for readers to interpret its meaning. An example of this is seen when Holden asks the taxi driver what happens to the ducks when the ice freezes? He isn’t talking about the ducks, but rather himself and what would become of him. Another symbolism is seen by how Holden's hunting hat acts as his barrier, or rather, protection from the world. Although I sorta hated Holden's personality since he’s such a jerk, I loved reading his perspective since he’s also hypocritical. Furthermore, this book was probably new and revolutionary when it was published but what I absolutely loved about it is that it was very modern at the same time. It reflects life and society and facades of society that we always do, but don’t often mean. An example is when he met a guy and told him we’re glad to have met each other, when Holden's mind is actually saying “I’m not really glad we have met, but if you want to stay alive, you sort of have to say these kinds of things”. This phrase also suggests that Holden acknowledges there is a social construct in society. I can also see this book as being a journey of life (coming from a jerk) since Holden questions life, peoples relationships and even himself, even if he doesn’t find satisfaction within himself. The title of the book was genisley thought out and I would have to give Salinger a standing ovation for that. I personally believe that this is the perfect title for the book and might be my favorite title ever. “The catcher in the rye” (title) refers to how Holden wants to protect the innocent, that is children, since whenever he encounters a child there’s a positive affirmation. Holden acts as the boundary between childhood and adulthood (hence him being a teenager) and the “catcher” refers to how Holden “catches” children before delving into adulthood (the rye). The rye’s imagery is used for the transition phase of adolescence to adulthood. So before they jump into the world as adults or fall into the adult world he wants to catch them, therefore, playing a heroic role by becoming a savior of children. Holden wants to be the savior of children before turning into adults, since his interactions with adults always seem to be negative. The allusions constructed in this book was so perfectly written. There is a part that I haven’t seen anyone talk about at all. I would like to end this review by stating an allusion and providing food for thought, and this thought is quite disturbing. I believe Holden was victim of child abuse. When he visits one of his teachers at the end of the book his teacher awakes him by stroking his hair while he is sleeping. Prior to that, Holden mentions that one of his classmates committed suicide. Did his classmate commit suicide since he was a victim of child abuse from the same teacher? Is Holden's character constructed since he was molested as a child? After all, can we blame Holden for acting the way he did? Overall, the catcher in the rye was an absolute blast read from start to end. J.D. Singler perfectly conveys aspects of psychoanalysis, philosophy and culture through the mind of a sixteen year old.

3.25 catching ★★★✩✩
This book is for you if… you feel tempted by the idea to read what is considered to be the US-American predecessor of today's young-adult genre. You will meet the ultimate crossover of coming-of-age x classics that offers interesting characters and insights into the life of white male young adults during the middle of the 20th century.

I can't believe that - for a change - I don't have to wonder why countless people rate books such as Jane Eyre or Pride and Prejudice so awfully high because I got one question "Which version of this have you read because I certainly had a different experience?"It is ironic however that this classic has a way lower rating than classics such as the ones from above but I'd prefer this any time 😅 [insert confused puppy face here]. There were a couple of red flags for me as a feminist, for instance, stalking behaviour is dismissed as the romantic intentions of a shy boy instead of acknowledged as toxic and dangerous.⤐ What’s happening.

‘I’m always saying ‘Glad to’ve met you’ to somebody I’m not at all glad I met. If you want to stay alive, you have to say that stuff, though.’
