I kind of liked that nothing happened, and it's a classics so I can't complain. But I love Holden, the rest of the characters were pretty strange.

[Minor edits: 28 July 2015]Such a famous book - what can you say about it, which is new and interesting?It's so well-known that you almost think you have read it even when you haven’t. The story is simple. During the course of a weekend, school senior Holden Caulfield gives us an account of his life up to that point as he leaves the school from which he has been expelled. He tells of his roommates and teachers and his older brother RB, a big writer in Hollywood; Phoebe, his adored younger sister and Allie, his younger brother who died. Holden has a number of desultory encounters through the course of the several days; with roommates, a teacher who probably wants to molest him, some out of town girls in a bar and most poignantly with Phoebe as he sneaks into his family home, anxious to avoid his parents for as long as possible once they learn of his latest expulsion.I am about 40 years too old to get the maximum benefit from The Catcher in the Rye. To get the most out of it you probably have to have been a teenager in the fifties. Reading the book when you are old and full of life’s experiences, irrespective of how you have handled them, allows some detachment. We know how youthful anger, uncertainty, naïve hopefulness (witness the time when Holden wants to go away – anywhere, he just wants to go off somewhere with Sally - the idea quickly comes to nothing) and a more or less permanent state of directionlessness (I hope that is a word), and lack of fulfilment, can change over time. We know these feelings modify and dissipate over the years as hopes fade or a calling is found, skills are acquired and concrete obligations arise and have to be met. In short, we cope.Holden doesn’t cope. He does not apply himself. He is all over the place. He has been profoundly affected by the death of his younger brother. I was worried he was going to take his own life.I have to imagine how impactuous this book was in 1951. I know impactuous is not a word but Adele, one of my collaborators, used it when we were reviewing a film and when I said ‘I don’t think that’s a word, she replied, ‘Well, it should be!’ The Catcher in the Rye was impactuous then and still is now.

It's hard to judge this book for me since I'm having mixed feelings. For the first 2/3 of the book, I really worked through the pages like a school assignment trying to find the purpose of this story. Only by the last pages I somehow connected to Holden and I liked the last scene with Phoebe, him and the carousel.It's such a stupid question, in my opinion. I mean how do you know what you're going to do till you do it? The answer is, you don't. I think I am, but how do I know?The author is doing a great job picturing Holden as a troubled teenager with the attitude me-against-the-world whose emotions and thoughts change from one point to another every minute. I also had to get used to the language because its vocabulary and usage was old. Basically, I felt like reading the diary of a teenager where he just spits out every thought during his existential crisis. It was entertaining, depressing and annoying altogether. I wished I had read this in school to analyze all the details. I'm sure there is much more under the surface but I only could get a glimpse of it. What I clearly got was the change of roles by the end when Phoebe and Holden are at the carousel with the hunter hat. Even though the last chapter shows his typical characteristic rebellion, I felt that somehow he had grown up a bit.

Unlike most folks I did not read this book in high school. It wasn’t until my daughter was assigned the book to read the summer before her senior year in high school that I decided to pick it up and read it with her. It is definitely a classic and gave my daughter and I a lot to talk about. I found the main character to be a bit melodramatic and he rather annoyed me. I think if I had read this book when I was 18 instead of 46 I might’ve had a different opinion.

Well I was expecting to find something in this book that wasn't there. It's a renowned classic a 'book to read before you die' after all. The first half I was sorry for Holden Caulfield his agony at the loss of his brother, his isolation, his teenaged angst, but in the end I was irritated by him and the writing style. I maybe should have read this when I was younger but for me it didn't work. 1 1/2 *
In China , this book affect a lot of peaple . I think it's good , it worth to reading .

Holden Caulfield is an unhappy rich boy who has done a runner from his posh secondary school. Like many adolescents, he feels that the world is an alienating place awash with phonies. Holden regales the reader with “this madman stuff” that happened over three days in December 1949 just before he left his school, and in New York.Part of what makes The Catcher in the Rye so good is the portrait of Holden Caulfield. The reader is placed so convincingly and memorably inside his head, and it all rings completely true. It’s extraordinary. The more so that J.D. Salinger wrote it when he was in his thirties, and having seen active service in WW2. The Catcher in the Rye remains the definitive novel of teen angst and alienation, and must surely still resonate with many teens. Mature readers may simply view Holden as a privileged whinging rich kid with no real worries. Either way, The Catcher in the Rye remains completely convincing, compelling and timeless. 5/5

3/5 StarsYou know, this book had the potential to be really great. It started off that way. Within the first few chapters I was quickly enjoying the seemingly endless humor, and the way Holden was blunt about everything he experienced in life. It was refreshing. However, the two things that attracted me to the novel in the first place, really ended up taking away from it, too. So yes, while I enjoyed the wittiness that came with seeing through Holden's eyes, I also quickly became tired of it. In the beginning, his humorous comments were fantastic. But after two hundred pages of the same joke told over and over, just in different context? Um. No thank you. That gets old.Another thing. Holden was really whiny, and quite stupid (now I sound mean). Now, now, don't get all upset with me. I do realize this book is "symbolizing" adolescence (or something like that), but I never acted this dull at sixteen. Really. His dumb choices were annoying me. Though, again, I realize how without his choices, there would be no book. All in all, I liked him and I hated him.I don't want it to seem like this book was all bad - since it wasn't - I did enjoy how Holden felt everything but learned to hide it because he knew society didn't really care how he felt. I think we can all relate to that feeling. Overall, it's good that I finally got around to reading this! It was a long time coming. So despite my severely average rating, I wouldn't mind coming back to this one for a re-read. Holden is definitely a unique character - you know, in his own annoying/whiny way.

This book gets a lot of flak because its protagonist, Holden Caulfield, is crude and random in his thought patterns. But that's only a superficial view. A careful reading of the book shows that underneath all of the swearing, sour opinions, and teenage angst, is the story of a boy who has been traumatized. He has PTSD, particularly as a result of the death of his brother Allie and another boy at one of his former schools, James Castle. As his mentor tells him, Holden is "confused and frightened and even sickened by human behavior" (246), and this is the reason for his "bad" attitude and disruptive behavior. The phoniness of the world makes him sick, literally so, and reviewing his troubled memories is part of his personal healing. In fact, far from being "immoral," Holden is probably the only MORAL person of the book (aside from his little sister Phoebe). He is the only one who recognizes how false and pretentious people can be, and is also the only one who calls the world out for it. I get that the content of this book may not be appropriate for younger audiences, and others may balk at the frequent cussing. But let's not make the mistake of thinking Holden is rotten — he's the only one in this book who has a soul.

Controversial opinion time- I really don't get the hype behind this classic. Had my English Lit class did this novel instead of An Inspector Calls, I would have been absolutely bummed about it (and possibly failed my final exams by ranting too much!) Following a young troubled boy called Holden, who finds himself being kicked out of school and struggling with depression. He doesn't feel any joy and decides to run off to New York City before his family find out the truth. During this period, he reminisces about his past and connects again with some old flames, including a girl he used to like and meeting up again with his younger sister. I just didn't feel anything positive radiating from the characters, nor the story-line. I wasn't keen on Holden as a character. I did like the NYC setting and thought the pacing flowed alright. Other than that, not a fan!

***1 lousy star***I know this is a classic... I know it's a loved book over generations.... but man! did I hate it!! o.OI have to say that I rarely give 1 star ratings. And when I do, I feel like I'm being mean or unfair to someone's hard work, but some books - mostly classical books for me - are just pretty damn terrible. I could not, if I wanted to, find one thing I liked in this story and that should say it all. For any potential reader who may see this and thinks about picking up this book, let me save you the suspense: it's about a kid who tells the reader what's happened to him over the last couple of weeks. Yep, that's it...and it all felt like ramblings. There's no actual plot whatsoever. "The catcher in the rye" is also poorly written and I simply cannot understand the buzz around it. #sorrynotsorry

I was pretty torn with how to rate this book. This was a re-read for me. I first read it in high school and had forgotten many details. I originally had rated it 4 stars but I now rate it 4.5 stars. What most appealed to me when I read it in high school was the writing style. Yes, the character is highly flawed and often annoying, but it was the first novel I had read that was written in such a relatable and conversational style. This time around it was less the writing style and more the story that captivated me. I was worried Caulfield would be more annoying to me as an adult, but I found the opposite. He broke my heart. In a good way.
You know how some people mislead you by saying nothing happens in a book, when something actually does? This isn't one of those times. Nothing happened in this book.

Diverti-me duplamente porque o li em português e em Inglês. Holden Caulfield ♥️“If you really want to hear about it, the first thing you'll probably want to know is where I was born ... and all that David Copperfield kind of crap.”“I'm the most terrific liar you ever saw in your life. It's awful.”“People always clap for the wrong things.”“The thing is, it's really hard to be roommates with people if your suitcases are much better than theirs.”“The best thing, though, in that museum was that everything always stayed right where it was”“I'd just be the catcher in the rye and all. I know it's crazy, but that's the only thing I'd really like to be.”“Don't ever tell anybody anything. If you do, you start missing everybody.”8/198 - Estados Unidos da América
3.5 stars…

I honestly don't know where to begin with this mess of a novel. It was repetitive and boring. The main character had his head up his own ass through this entire book, which is not surprising since he is a teenager. I know that I was supposed to probably sit around afterwards and discuss how profound I found everything. I instead rolled my eyes and just dismissed the book as soon as I finished with it. This is a coming of age story of Holden Caulfield. After being told that he will be expelled because of his lack of work at his private school, Holden goes to New York City so that he can have some time to break it to his parents he has been booted from another school.Holden is lazy and critical of everyone around him. Heck there were several profound comments that he made about pimply guys and ugly girls that just made him sound like such an awesome person to be around, one wonders why he has no close friends.I think that J.D. Salinger was definitely going for something here I think to speak about how so many teens feel alienated from the world and people around them. But I didn't get the sense that Holden was alienated, just bored with everyone because he held everyone except for his sister, and his two brothers in total disdain. The writing was not great. It was repetitive to the point that I was able to totally call what Holden was going to say. I never want to hear the words "They really can" ever again.That's the thing about girls.Every time they do something pretty, even if they're not much to look at, or even if they're sort of stupid, you fall in love with them, and then you never know where the hell you are.Girls.Jesus Christ.They can drive you crazy.They really canYou poor thing. Falling in love with a girl that is not attractive and dumb. And yet they still don't want you. Almost every time somebody gives me a present, it ends up making me sad.So profound. I mean I hardly rolled my eyes that hard after I read this. The flow was also pretty awful. I think it was because the story just went on and on and on to the point I was rooting for a bad end for Holden. Can you tell that I couldn't stand this character?The setting of New York honestly didn't feel real at all. Maybe because Holden was so far up his own butt, the only thing that gets described are other people (specifically girls/women) and how attractive they are or in the case of this book, how ugly he finds them. The ending I think was supposed to make me think. It just once again made me roll my eyes hard. What can one say about a character that I don't think matures at all, and still sees the problems with everyone and not himself.

There is nothing that I could NOT appreciate from The Catcher in the Rye. I got totally absorbed in this book, you could say that. As a bildungsroman novel, this one went far beyond my expectations! The conflict was Man vs Self. Holden Caulfield against his ignorance and insecurity (you’d figure that out 'til you read the last page, by the way). Holden is unique. He is the iconic of a rebellion, yet he never really does fatal thing or whatsoever. He is a pacifist as hell, and even his roommate (Stardlater) had hit him, fractured him, Holden’d just rather let it go even though it’s always about losing. Always. Oh, poor Holden. I’d only been in about two fights in my life, and I lost both of them. I’m not too tough. I’m a pacifist, if you want to know the truth. Dialogs are pretty less than narratives, but I could still enjoy it. Like DF said, it has the first-person smartass narrative so no wonder that Holden has a great sense of humor.I was surrounded by jerks. I’m not kidding.  “What the hellya reading?” he said.“Goddam book.” I found myself laughing so hard at many parts, but the ending got my eyes sweating. Ok, I meant I was crying. There. I admit it. The ending was unpredictable and really touchy for me. Oh, wait. Where I have been all this times? I kind of feel pity for myself 'cause I read this novel just now. THIS YEAR, Shelly? Really? Poor me. Hahah. Oh, and the last thing. My most favorite quote: Everybody goes through phases and all, don’t they? My favorite part? When Holden asks about the ducks in the Central Park Lagoon xD He really is worried about the ducks xD I never tought he really meant it lolWell, last but not least, let me say thank you to DF and Dhira for this amazing book recommendation. I also wanna say thanks to my Buddy Read, Marina. Guys, you all rooooooooooooock!

“Among other things, you'll find that you're not the first person who was ever confused and frightened and even sickened by human behavior. You're by no means alone on that score, you'll be excited and stimulated to know. Many, many men have been just as troubled morally and spiritually as you are right now. Happily, some of them kept records of their troubles. You'll learn from them—if you want to. Just as someday, if you have something to offer, someone will learn something from you. It's a beautiful reciprocal arrangement. And it isn't education. It's history. It's poetry.” Okay, this was just great ... Actually, I was very reluctant towards this book till once I read a few pages in library and I was totally taken by the passive language used in it. (That's what makes this book a figure of contraversy in literature) The protagonist actually felt so close - as an introvert bibliophile young adult one is passing thro' similar problems (but usually not at that extent as in the book) with changes in secretion of harmones at this age. The book describes the journey of a 17 - years old boy (Holden Caulfield) towards alienation which is actually an act of self-protection with the cynical sense of superiority, this isolation is some stabilization in a messed up life according to Caulfield but is actually the source of all his problems. He actually fears the change and it's complexity which leads him to a fantasy of adult world as superficial and hypocritical. He even fantasizes himself as 'The Cather in the Rye' (the protector of children from falling into adulthood) which looks like a Heroic act. The entire book and espicially the climax is structured magnificiently. The elements, symbols and motifs are skillfully used in texts and are so touching. A remarkable transition is described at the end not to be spoiled.

Published in 1951, this book is considered a classic of 20th-century literature. It was the inspiration for well-known musicians such as Billy Joel, Guns N' Roses and Green Day, among others. Besides, it's public knowledge that John Lennon's killer, after shooting him, was waiting for the police with this novel in his hands. He'd bought a copy of the book—his favorite—en route to murder John Lennon; in it he wrote "This is my statement," and signed as Holden Caulfield.I can imagine why the book caused so much controversy at the time: Holden Caulfield, the protagonist and narrator of this story, exposes the thoughts that cross his mind without any kind of filter. He does so using the language available to him, one of a teenager's own, with all that that implies (insults, repetitions, references to the sexual acts and transparency). In his ideas and conceptions about the people he interacts with and the places he transits to, is hiding a strong social critique that is worth discussing as a reader.I believe that the author managed to write with solidity from the voice of a teenager and capture the extremism, spontaneity and emotional lability that many of us have probably experienced as we went through that stage of our lives.I found many mixed reviews of this book but personally I enjoyed reading it so much and kept wondering why I hadn’t picked it up earlier.

You mean to tell me this damn book is controversial, and it damn well gets censored and banned in a lot of damn schools? I damn well can't believe it. Damn. It is just so damn offensive. It really is.On a serious note, this book hardly comes off as offensive by contemporary standards. The vernacular is so 1951 - including the swearing. It's kind of neat looking back to the past in that regard. The only F bombs Salinger dared to write were all on one page, all within quotation marks, citing graffiti Holden had found. How literary censorship has changed in the past several decades (for the better) is astounding. If you don't know '40s slang you don't even catch the innuendos.My feelings about this book: it has a narrator whom the author strongly and effectively characterizes (though his catchphrases get tiresome after the first dozen repetitions), hence the two stars instead of one. However, I cannot relate to Holden or his experiences / apparent emotions in the slightest. The book lacks any semblance of a plot. It tries to simplify a fictional reality for this teen to the point that it becomes unrealistically plain.What's all the hoopla? I mean, he's a confused, angsty, hypocritical teenager. Yay. Profound.

Didn’t remember much of this book. Believe it was assigned reading in high school but of course I was too young to understand anything. Now I see it in a new light. Holden Caulfield is having a breakdown, and perhaps something even more serious (because of ending).The language is the voice of the character so is idiosyncratic and vernacular. It reads as dated now, as well as a little wordy. So many writing rules were broken!! I love books that break all the rules and yet are deemed classics. Also funny to remember how absolutely tedious this book was to read when we were all a bit younger.An unappealing unreliable narrator who thinks only of himself — is this some sort of metaphor for youth? Young people still hate this book, because they do not want to see themselves reflected here, in any way.

Re-read it after 20 years, sure I would be disappointed. Back then I had adored it, was Holden's age (and probably had a serious crush on him!) and related so much to his every thought. Well, the magic still holds, even though now he'd classify me too as a "phony" grown-up...I usually don't forget books yet I couldn't remember much about the plot. Rightly so cause there isn't one: we just follow Holden who's as lonely and depressed and weak and sick of people as we are and we feel we're not alone and that's all we need. I wouldn't ask for more. PerfectionPS: the Greek translation from the early '70s is extremely (yet delightfully) dated! I wonder what the writing style and choice of words in the original 1951 English reads like! I must attempt it someday.

So I must be one of the very few who didn't read this in high school. So yes this was a first read for me at 50+ years of age.I think for me personally the thing that I enjoyed the most about the book was the colloquial speech that gave it a very real time and place in our culture. I liked the emotions of nostalgia that came from reading THe Catcher and the Rye, a book that is so grounded in a particular time and place. I know that is not what people are generally drawn to this book for, it's the teenage angst and rebellion of Holden, but as that time of my life is way in the distant past (angst - I'm still rebellious) for me that wasn't the aspect I was most moved by.

I finished this today and wow I really loved it which was somewhat unexpected. It's hard to say how I would have felt about it had I read it in high school. I don't think teenage Amanda would really have liked it or cared at all about Holden. I loved Holden even though he was a total spoiled pain in the ass. I felt his pain and his loneliness. I'm not sure I really get what the big deal is about this book and why it seems to be the quintessential America high school assignment but I'm really glad I finally got around to reading it.

The book itself didn't actually "inform my sexuality" as the shelf implies but my used copy had a very realistic sketch of a penis drawn somewhere in the middle and I hadn't actually seen a penis that up close before, so all in all I'd have to say it was very informative.
I would rather light myself on fire than read another sentence of that again.

I'm going to start with a J.D. Salinger quote. It's his reaction to having a huge picture of his face on the back cover of the first printings of The Catcher in the Rye. It's amazing."Let's say I'm getting good and sick of bumping into that blown-up photograph of my face on the back of the dust-jacket. I look forward to the day when I see it flapping against a lamp post, in a cold, wet Lexington Avenue wind."I've never felt this lonely reading a book before.Probably because the overall theme of the book is quite depressing; the protagonist, Holden Caulfield, being a lonely, miserable sixteen-year-old who gets kicked out of school (again) and takes to the streets of New York for three days, as his parents aren't expecting him to come home yet.It seems Holden is often regarded as a character that embodies what it's like to be a teenager. I can't say I agree with that at all. Sure, he's 'rebellious' - a word that I often hear being thrown around when people talk about teenage years - but for me being a teenager definitely hasn't felt like it did for Holden. Maybe that's just because Holden and I are polar opposites. I just couldn't relate to him at all. He's essentially everything I am not, personality-wise.I did find it slightly aggravating how Holden kept making comments on things relating to homosexuality. I understand that this book was published in 1951 and things were slightly different then, but I still don't think it's acceptable. Holden keeps picking fights, doesn't keep many opinions to himself, and is extremely hypocritical and negative, but I still found myself sympathising with him a few times. Especially because he constantly seeks human interaction but keeps being met with the raw distance that is stuck between him and the rest of the world, leaving him lonely and secluded after each conversation. Holden's thoughts are laid bare on each page; nothing is held back. He tells everything he feels and sees — everything that is true to him. Even things he himself doesn't completely understand.Salinger really did something with this one: Teachers were fired (and reinstated, luckily), copies of his book were removed from schools in the United States (The Catcher in the Rye ended up being one of the most censored books of the twentieth century), and John Lennon's assassin was found reading the book out loud to himself after the murder.That last piece of information fried at least a few of my brain cells.

For me, the beauty of this is its deceptive simplicity. Catcher is so readable and so accessible that people can approach it from a hundred different angles. For some it's allegorical, for others it's comedic, still others find it sad or disturbing. And then there are those like Mark David Chapman, John Hinckley, Jr., and Robert John Bardo who have unfairly made it a footnote for perversion and murder. Are we projecting something of ourselves on Salinger's canvas? I think maybe we are. I found this similar to another favorite novel of mine, Phillip Roth's 'Indignation' - both feature a teenage misfit who, in failing to assimilate at his expensive, predominantly white prep school, embarks on a path of self destruction. I can relate. My own life has been a procession of cyclical misadventures. I am sympathetic to Holden because he is dysfunctionally functioning - mostly by just being kind. He'll loan you his turtleneck even if he barely knows you, and he'll drop $10 in the nun's basket without being asked, and he'll watch over old Phoebe because he loves his little sister. Yeah, his future isn't all that bright, but his heart's in the right place and I'm a sucker for underdogs with good intentions."It rained all over the place. All the visitors that were visiting the cemetery started running like hell over to their cars. That's what nearly drove me crazy. All the visitors could get in their cars and turn on their radios and all and then go someplace nice for dinner - everybody except Allie. I couldn't stand it. I know it's only his body and all that's in the cemetery, and his soul's in heaven and all that crap, but I couldn't stand it anyway. I just wish he wasn't there. You didn't know him. If you'd known him, you'd know what I mean." (pg. 202)

Returned to this classic for the purpose of supporting my child through the 9th grade. But this oldie has something in it for everyone. I think I am far more moved as an adult to appreciate Holden's interweaving of perspective and loss of perspective. How tough it is to be a teenager. Its so obvious that what Holden suggests is true - that life happens in the digression. Its in the spaces between what is direct and indirect, it engagement in the moment and your reflection on it. Heartbreaking moment in the story (so many of them) is when the record he so lovingly bought for his sister breaks. Phoebe is an amazing character, and its equally poignant when she shows up with a suitcase at the museum and demands to go away with him, and that is the thing that shows him he can no longer run. Unquestionably, for all of the angst, Holden Caulfield is authentic, and Holden Caulfield is loved. Its an amazing speech near the end that his former English teacher gives - about figuring out what you love and going for it. Its kind of like the record, the hunting hat, and other experiences he creates out of nothing. You have to figure out what matters, what is worth a possible shattering of the heart, and then go for it with everything you've got. What a shame that these books are wasted on the young. I hope my fifteen year old has the opportunity to read it again someday too. And to take it in. This one stands the test of time.

Seriously, people??Why is everybody in America truly obsessed with this book??I really hated it!!I didn't understand the plot at all, there were some parts that were there just to make space and I didn't understand the ending at all!!We had to read for our English class back in 2012 during our exchange year with a German and a Denmark girls and none of us understood anything. The entire class talked about it with emotion and we were like "what the hell is this".Sorry, America. I love you, but I don't love this book.En serio, gente ??¿Por qué todos en Estados Unidos están realmente obsesionados con este libro ??Realmente lo odié!!No entendía la trama en absoluto, había algunas partes que estaban allí sólo para hacer espacio y yo no entendía el final en absoluto!!Tuvimos que leerlo para nuestra clase de Inglés por allá en 2012 durante nuestro año de intercambio con una alemana y una dinamarquesa y ninguna de nosotras entendíamos nada. Toda la clase hablaba de ello con emoción y nosotras estábamos como "¿qué demonios es esto?".Lo siento, América. Te quiero, pero no me gusta este libro .

Well, I never thought I would be rating this book 4 Stars, but I sure am. To me, Holden Caulfield came across as an extremely sad, depressed and lonely sixteen year old who is distraught over the death of his younger brother Allie resulting with an inability to interact with people or cope with everyday life. Even with his obvious psychological problems, he exuded intelligence and was compassionate towards the Nuns and small children as well as his sister Phoebe. Yes, Holden's lingo is annoying and abusive, but its fast pace throughout certainly fit his emotional roller coaster.Originally published in 1951, I found the book insightful and quite relevant even today. Am glad to finally know the significance of the book's title.

I have mixed feelings. I started out really enjoying the book, and then I wasn’t enjoying it for a while and then towards the end I started enjoying it again. I’m glad I read it but it’s not a 5 star. I’m being generous with 4 stars. Probably closer to 3.5! I, like many offers, found Holden to be snarky and self absorbed. I think I would have had a different experience if I read this when I was a teenager and not an adult. I do recommend giving it a read though.

Here's a tribute to my old teacher from high school who let us read The Catcher when we were just the right age for it. The book never really left me, and I can honestly say it sort of shaped me. Thank you, Mr.B., wherever you are!

I initially rated this 1 star when I first got on here because I hated in high school. However, after seeing some really bad takes on twitter and realizing what kind of state Holden is in, I think I need to revisit it. Perhaps I was too immature back then. We shall see.

i know holden sometimes gets a bad rep for being a whiney teen, but i actually really like him and this book!

Kristen ParkesMrs. EbarviaWorld Literature Honors11-19-07“If you really want to hear about it, the first thing you'll probably want to know is where I was born and what my lousy childhood was like, and how my parents were occupied and all before they had me, and all that David Copperfield kind of crap, but I don't feel like going into it, if you want to know the truth.” And Thus begins the novel Catcher in The Rye by J.D. Salinger. The story takes place in mid 1950’s in New York City, where adolescent Holden Caulfield roams around searching for a place to fit in. When Holden learns that once again he has been kicked out of the prestigious private all boys school in which he is enrolled in for this month, he decides to leave the quiet school life and return home once again to New York City.Throughout this novel, I found many interesting aspects. The dialogue that Salinger wrote for Holden is truly capturing, and as a reader I begin to feel as though I grew up next door to the Caulfield’s my entire life. There is something about the way the main character goes about things, in such ways that no other person would be likely to think of. Holden is extremely dramatic, making it comedic and enrapturing for the reader. It was also interesting the amount of low self-esteem for which J.D Salinger provided for his main character. Holden is often depressed and this is clearly expressed at many points in the novel. Holden uses sarcasm, and although once again comedic, it makes it difficult for a reader to decide whether or not he is thinking. This point leads us into the next idea about J.D Salinger’s The Catcher in the Rye, his weaknesses. As hilarious and awkward Holden Caulfield was throughout the novel, as a reader, a majority of my time in the novel I felt confused and unable to keep up with the main character. Continuously, I would find myself re-reading pages, and even chapters to attempt to understand what was going on in Holden’s life at that moment. Another weakness clearly expressed was the fact that there was hardly a plot. Yes, it may be naïve that I like a love story, and a happy ending, but this novel had neither. It did not have so much as a rise or fall of the protagonist. In fact, it was as though there was a rollercoaster of rises and falls for the protagonist, but none of them significant. This caused me to be bored with the novel, and once again have trouble getting through it without drifting off to other places in my mind.Although it may be true that a large portion of the United States thought that this novel was excellent and recommend it to all coming of age teens, I for one did not enjoy this novel; despite the comedy and intrigue. Even though this novel was not for me, I would recommend it to anyone whom enjoys male coming of age tales, for they would perhaps find it a better read than I have.

If you ask me what The Catcher in the Rye is about, I wouldn't know what to tell you. I'll just probably stare at you and just sorta push you to read the book without any questions whatsoever. Rating and especially reviewing this book is so hard. I did love the book though, I hated it too a little bit, it confused me a lot and it even made me cry at some parts. The truth is, I'm obsessed. I found myself researching about this novel and each one of its characters when I finished it. I started reading some phrases again. I even spent like two days thinking nothing but Holden and what could've happened to him after everything. For some reason, Holden's thoughts are very much appealing to me. I LIKE how he thinks. He's the kind of fictional character I WANT TO MEET IN REAL LIFE AND TALK TO. He affects me A LOT. And that happens rarely to me. Yes, I like characters a lot. And I fangirl all the time but only few can pierce through me and affect me so much. Holden did that. He makes me sad. He really does. He makes me want to change my views. Yes, maybe he does have a VERY depressing view of the world and let's admit it, he does hate a lot of things but despite all of that, I still feel a lot of sympathy towards him.I wouldn't say anything anymore because I don't think my voice about this novel is not that important anyway. But I'll say this: The Catcher In The Rye DESERVES to be a classic. Maybe it won't work with EVERYONE but what's new with that? J.D. Salinger is a brilliant novelist and so is this book. He and Holden may not capture every readers heart but he have mine. Just from the very first chapter. I have to appreciate that. I don't think I'll ever forget this book. Ever.

This is my first book read listed in 100 Must Read Books for Men (Bloomsbury) and I liked it. It is devoid of the usual melodrama and direct in its storytelling approach. I also got very interested on this because I read in 500 Must Read Books for Men that the assassin of J. F. Kennedy read this book prior to the assassination and the guy you attempted to kill Ronald Reagan was also fond of this book. On the more positive side, George W. Bush said in one interview that he got inspiration from this book when he was growing up.Just like Great Gatsby, this is one of the required readings in high school all over the U.S. I think it is because this novel's main message is that teenagers normally pass through a phase where they feel alienated and misunderstood. In the novel, the main protagonist, Holden was kicked out from school and he ran away thinking that his parents would not understand him. He had this dream of "catching children falling on cliffs" (where the title came from) which was actually a metaphor since in the end it was his baby sister, Phoebe, who made him go back home (thereby saving his future).The only thing that prevented me from rating this with 5 stars is the language - the colloquial English, the cursing, etc. However, it is said to be the way teenagers spoke in the 50's in New York.

Pencey Prep School is like a machine that produces "little soldiers for the Emperor". See Little Shirley Temple's first movie.But just like the kids on the merry-go-round, it is against the rules to let them know that some of them won't make it.  Some of them will never reach the golden ring and some will fall off...but it is against the rules to warn them of this.It is against the rules to tell students that they are only qualified to die in some phoney war...and some students will learn to treat their superiors like princes and be phonies and succeed because you will know how to play the game. But as these phonies rise to the top it will make a very crazy world to live in. The world that Holden finds himself in. The crazy world that Salinger lived in. "The pretend that everything is alright", world. The phony world.

I enjoyed the ride.but apparently not for the same reason as everyone.I loved the hero.he was an unusual guy but really funny.He made me laugh out loud more than once.However I didn't find him as smart as everyone seems to.he was a lot of things:sensitive, lost,realist .I loved getting inside his mind and found his way of seeing things really interesting .still, using the world "depressive" in every paragraph and for every situation doesn't make anyone smart.I didn't like much the end,or the lack of one..I was at least expecting someone to die lol.Maybe I would had enjoyed this book more when I was 16 .I will never know.

Done reading The Catcher in the Rye. Narrated in first-person perspective, it's exactly the kind of writing tone I need for my first and only novel (assuming there's one). Holden Caulfield and I shared a number of similarities. One, we love tennis. Two. we use the term "and all" when we talk. Three, we're skinny - we choose to eat light. Though. Holden smokes a lot. This is the lifestyle that surely kills me of Pulmonary Tuberculosis.This novel instantly becomes my new favorite - no phony talk here. Thanks a lot for the recommendation Ma'am Melanie Nazareno!

I am aware that you either love this book or you don't there is really no in-between. I fall into the first category, and I am very glad I decided to read this novel.  Holden Caulfield may be the most "alive" character I have ever came across. His quest for authenticity, his hypocrisy and loneliness really strikes you into the heart.I can understand how this book can deeply change your life, depending the state of your mind and situation you are when you come across it. It is still a bit early, but it may have changed mine.

I waited until I was 41 to read The Catcher in the Rye. I could have waited longer...I hated this book. The protagonist was a jerk, and I think there are more relevant "coming of age" stories for today's teens than this one-- like Looking for Alaska.Oh, well, at least I can say I read it, and add it to the list of outdated classics I will never read again.Perhaps, I am just not smart enough to get it. Nah, that's not it...

From this book, you can learn how to write a novel without a plot. Actually, plot is nowhere. The full novel is full of rubbish of a dropout sixteen year old boy. Though sometimes he makes sense and says some fine dialogues but most of the time he is phony. At that stage of life, I think everyone has faced more or less such situation. No kidding. Indeed. Hahaha...

This book wasn't awful but it wasn't necessarily 'good' I found some parts interesting and some parts extremely boring. But it doesn't deserve a 2 star rating and it doesn't deserve a 4 star rating.Its just an eh book. Thats all I can say about it.
what a lovely charming book; i am so glad i didn't read this when i was 16!
Very easy to read and very well written. It grabbed me from the first page, I just wish there was more of it.

It's about a sixteen-year-old guy's adventures roaming around New York City and talking to people after he gets kicked out from another school.Holden Caulfield also has a big personality and he keeps up amazing dialogue throughout the whole novel. I had no choice but to like him. I love how he hates so many things and that he feels sorry for almost everybody. There were so many contradictions too, like how he'd say he hates movies but still goes to them on certain circumstances even when he has the choice not to, or when he says he wouldn't like Sally to come with him somewhere far away but asks her anyway, or when he seems like a pretty smart dude in general but he always acts so foolish. But I didn't mind it. Especially after watching the Crash Course Literature episode about The Catcher in the Rye, and it said the book's about preserving innocence and also about change, and then the contradictions finally made sense to me. Apparently, that's what it means to be a catcher in the rye. To preserve innocence. It was also interesting to learn that "sort of" appears 179 times in the novel. Thanks, John Green!Man, I loved this book so much. Holden will be among my list of memorable characters, for sure.

I picked it up soon after I'm done with 'the splendid things we planned' which has a central character on the same line as that of Holden Caulfiend. Both are stories of coming of age boys, troubled with (superficial) phony world, the inability of copying with system, of something protagonist are missing on. It's the struggle while awaking to the realities and the idealism they believe existed, during childhood. The ones who listen to others get through this without much of hassles but the few who cannot believe in norms, have tough phase finding out reality by themselves. Both these protagonist have this tough phase.The main character Holden, unable to get along with world, doesn't himself want to. He's dropped out of college, has fight with roomie and leaves safe place in dark night to get troubled more into open world. Since money is no big issue, he keeps stumbling from one experience into other. The character calls lying, conceited people phony n himself keeps lying unnecessarily. In tough situations, he still gets trapped in imagination of being shot with bullets, signifies his unwillingness to wake up. His conversation with Sally about eloping is fantasy shows running away from problems than stay put and fight. He adores his siblings, Allie and Phoebe. Their world is of innocence, simplified and something Holden knows well. He talks his mind to little Phoebe who understands the gist - that he's in problem and he should do something for that. When she asks 'name something you'd like to be', that shows she knows the answer to his problem. But Holden runs in fantasy again, being a one catcher in rye and saving kids from falling off. Saving comes easily to him coz he's suffering, and wants to help others. Like he helps the nuns, and the kids at museum, or repairing skating board for a tiny girl. Maybe coz he himself is in need but he can't receive it well when his teacher tries. In Mr Antolini's world - “you're riding for--it's a special kind of fall, a horrible kind. The man falling isn't permitted to feel or hear himself hit bottom. He just keeps falling and falling. The whole arrangement's designed for men who, at some time or other in their lives, were looking for something their own environment couldn't supply them with. Or they thought their own environment couldn't supply them with. So they gave up looking. They gave it up before they ever really even got started” some of them never get started while the few - they learn their lessons right have chances they shine bright in future. I wish there be Mr Antolini for each such student. Antolini is what he needed then - someone to love and looked up to, who also pays good ear to the confusion he's trapped in.Though this character is little shadowy- just so in Holden's mind. Since he cant believe his helper, he gets more unsettled.About relationships and sex, he has desires but lacks the courage to pursue them. He likes Jane but never calls her. He backs off in hotel though he himself calls a hooker. Throughout the book his interest in intimacy keeps popping. But like every other thing he's confused about it. It's all about the confusing adolescent. In various degrees everyone faces it; it's true individualism and due to simple prose n uncomplicated incidents it's easy to relate to it. No wonder books hits it off after so many years. A story, quite easy, evokes problems of even today's generation, openly. Wish they don't ban it so much.

“I'm quite illiterate, but I read a lot. ”-4.2/5The Catcher in the Rye is set around the 1950s and is narrated by a young man named Holden Caulfield. He does not reveal much about his whereabouts but makes clear that he studies in a school and has been expelled recently for failing in four out of five classes. Also he has been expelled out of a school for fourth time in a row.The story revolves pretty much around Holden, his encounters with different people like his history teacher, his dormitory mates, mother of a guy who studies with him, a prostitute, his younger sister etc. After an uneventful night at dormitory he decides he’s had enough of this place and will go to Manhattan three days early, stay in a hotel, and not tell his parents that he is back. When he arrives at destination, he goes into a phone booth and considers calling several people, but for various reasons he decides against it. Finally he hires a cab and checks in at some lousy hotel. He spends time drinking at a bar, having unwanted events unfolding around him and finally go to sleep. Next day he calls up a girl he used to date, Sally, and convince her to go on a date with him, but the date goes wrong and he ends up offending her big time.Then he meets his old student adviser, who is now a student at University. He then decides to sneak into his own apartment building and wake his sister, Phoebe. He is forced to admit to Phoebe that he was kicked out of school, which makes her mad at him. He tells her his fantasy of being “the catcher in the rye,” a person who catches little children as they are about to fall off of a cliff. Holden ends his narrative here, telling the reader that he is not going to tell the story of how he went home and got “sick.” The Catcher is the Rye is undoubtedly a classic masterpiece by Salinger. If you observe the writing style then you would notice that he has written the book with such coolness and edginess that it makes you wonder how can an author think ahead of his time. The book is really simple but the deeper meaning it has within, is awakening, almost heart-touching. One should definitely read this book once in a lifetime!

“I'm the most terrific liar you ever saw in your life. It's awful. If I'm on my way to the store to buy a magazine, even, and somebody asks me where I'm going, I'm liable to say I'm going to the opera. It's terrible.” It took me years to start reading this cult classic and months to get through this short book. I didn't enjoy reading it but it was an interesting experience I'm not willing to repeat. The Catcher in the Rye follows one day in sixteen year old Holden's life from his POV, but his never-ending angst and destructive behaviour made it feel like a thousand years to me. Holden Caulfield is having one helluva time, or he would be if he wasn’t pretending half the time to be like everyone else and the other half confused, mad and ‘sweating like a bastard’ because of all the ‘phonies’ and expectations of all those around him. It was occasionally funny and insightful but the language, repetitive words and Holden’s angsty depressing mind was specially painful to get through. It took me five months of reading off and on to get through this short 214 pages and I’m so glad it is over at last. In the words of Holden, this nearly ‘killed me’.There are many ways of looking at this story and what Holden represents and the subtext of the story such as social commentary etc. But to me, Holden Caulfield is frustrating, selfish, self-destructive and very confused. He doesn’t know what he wants and doesn’t want to do anything to help himself or let anyone help him. This is Holden In a nutshell…Holden is a hypocrite because he calls other people who he thinks are fake or insincere a phony and then he goes and does the same thing. He lies a lot, fakes feelings or emotions he doesn't have and makes promises he has no intention of keeping. He refuses to take responsibility for his actions and grow up. He can see everyone else's faults except his own. This means …Holden Caulfield is a phony!

My impression is that this book is one you're supposed to read when you're 15-16 years old. Older than that and it'll lose it's appeal. Well, I was 18 when I read this, and I have to say I loved it. I didn't expect to love it, or even like it, but I did. I wish someone had shown it to me when I was 16, because it would have been helpful, very very helpful back then, but alas, that's not how it was meant to be and instead I found it 2 years later, and somehow found it was still highly relevant. Eventhough I'd somewhat put the teenage mentality behind me, it was still fresh in my mind (I was only 18), and a lot of the things I'd experienced and learned from were still shaping me a great deal. For all intents and purposes this book was still about me, about what I was going through. I think that even now, in my 20's I'd find some of it relevant. Back then, though, it meant I found myself agreeing with Holden Caufield all the way through. His opinions and feelings and ways of reacting are very similar to my own, and perhaps that's why I loved it. Because I saw my own emotions and sentiments reflected in someone else. And that meant the world to me. I thought I'd been alone with a lot of my opinions and points of views, suddenly I found I wasn't (bear with me, back then this was still a very new experience I hadn't found in many books). It was great. That's not the only thing I like about it, sure it affected me on a personal level, but it also taught me a lot. And there are two things about it I hope I never forget, two things I believe are worth remembering.Firstly, the reason for the title (I love it, but I won't spoil anything).Secondly, his unconditional love for his sister. I love my own brother fiercely, so this is something I understand and feel strongly about.For me, these are the things that made the book stick in my memory and makes it timeless.

It’s a book about kindness. Missing kindness. Looking for it, stumbling over it, clamoring for it. Wanting it. Wanting to give it. At that age when everything is so scary and confusing. It seems easy, and it isn’t. it isn’t easy, yet it is. And there is nothing much to go off of, but you and your own thoughts and fears and longings and terrible terrible doubts. So much sensitivity, and nobody to share it with. So much loneliness. Didn’t we all have it when we were 18? Didn’t we all go through it? I felt for Holden, and that catcher in the rye poem, that catcher in the rye image, that thing he wanted to do, catching, it made me cry. It makes me cry even now. Holden Caulfield, 18, flanks out of Pencey Prep, a private school full of dolts and morons. Of course he does. Nothing makes sense. Nothing has any purpose. Everything is boring. Nobody understands him. So he sets off to go home, scared of what his parents will think, him flanking out of school again. Good parents. Good home in New York. How he gets there, what happens when he does, all around Christmas time, through the snow and cold and the Central Park with a frozen pond, that’s where you’ll go reading this book. I’ll leave you here. It’s a beautiful journey. And the ducks? I’m still wondering about the ducks. You’ll know what I mean once you read it.

This is the classic book that was controversial way back when it was written. In this one, Holden is being kicked out of another school. He doesn't want to go home and tell his parents yet so we follow him for a couple of days and his observations of the world.This book identifies with teenagers as we get a view of Holden and his angst with the world. I would have loved to have read this book while I was a teenager. That being said, even though I am far removed from my teenager years I had no problem identifying with the main character. This novel is a wonderful look into a character. Holden doesn't have a sense of direction even though he is smart. He feels like he doesn't belong with anyone and I imagine all of us at one time has felt like this. He tries to find fulfillment in various things but none of them work. The book also touches upon loss of loved ones and other subjects.I can see why this book was a controversy when it was released. The language (it is outdated) can be a little vulgar and so is some of the material. That isn't the point of the story though. It is about Holden and how he is feeling at the moment. I believe one's connection to this book depends how they feel about the main character. He can offend some readers but for me, I was immediately connected and I can see why many consider this book a classic.

So anyway, I want to tell you about what a phoney Holden Caulfield was when we first met years and years ago. He was always whining and smoking and drinking and trying to pass himself off as a nonchalant adult when really he was just a flunkee. He killed me, he really did. A real pain in the ass bastard, if you know what I mean. Anyway, I'm not saying that he didn't have his good qualities, just that you had to look really hard for them and then they still weren't enough to make you glad you put in the effort. And did I tell you what a sadsack, phoney bastard he was? It just depressed hell out of me. Old Phoebe, now she was swell. She killed me. And Old Antolini (the Mrs., not the Mr.). Yeah, they were grand. But Holden was such a phoney and definitely not worth a second encounter but I went ahead with it anyway because my daughter thought he was a classic she shouldn't miss and now there's two of us just depressed as hell.

i adored this book! the writing style was very easy to read for a classic and overall very enjoyable. the book basically doesn't have that much of a plot, and is certainly very character-driven, which is usually something I don't tend to enjoy that much, but I was never once bored during the whole book! i completely understand why someone would hate this book - there's a fine line between despise and love, because the main character is quite unlikeable. holden caulfield hates everyone and everything, and he complains and moans throughout the whole book. the constant use of the words "phony", "dopey", and "lousy" got a bit repetitive sometimes, even though i wasn't hugely bothered with it i can still understand why that would be annoying for some. i ended up giving this five stars, because there was just something that i really loved about this book, even though i'm not completely sure what that actually is *shifty eyes emoji*

Everything about The Catcher In The Rye that can be said has already been said, this is not another critique. It didn't touch me that deeply - rather it's memorable for how strongly it affected others. Like my beloved young friend Paul - so full of angst and discontent. He felt a common bond with Salinger, a voice that articulated his feelings of ‘disconnect’. I haven't heard from Paul in years, his mother tells me that he's now a reclusive shut-in struggling with manic depression. The good news is he's still a voracious reader, Paul friggin LOVES books & this was his all-time favorite. Then there is Chapman who was carrying a copy of Catcher in the Rye when he shot John Lennon. I'm just saying...

This book is amazing in many ways. Amazing this chap, Holden Caulfield, and his definition of not wanting to do anything in particular with his life exept saving some innocent kids maybe while they play in the rye. It is great to think this way, you know, fresh... Living in a world were one has to decide early to become an attorney or a physician leaves little space for sincerity, kindness, soul. I think Holden was a rebel (with a cause, but without actually knowing it) against the coldness of world set in stone.

...you'll find that you're not the first person who was confused and frightened and even sickened by human behavior.I'm trying to read some of the classics most mentioned in other books, so that I can better understand these references. Although I felt sad for Holden - I definitely think there is more to his depression than your average teenage angst - I was somewhat irritated by every second sentence ending with ...and all. The ending was also a let-down for me. I think if I read this when I was a teenager it would have had a much bigger impact.

Here's the thing about this book, nothing happens in it, it's just about a teenage boy wasting his time. The writer did an amazing job drawing his protagonist's character, Holden reminded me a lot of my teenage brother, but he didn't build on that personality, he didn't help us understand it and didn't even give it a chance to grow. This book is just a portrait of an obnoxious person. Or maybe I just didn't understand it.

Well, it is not what I expected… and I don’t mean that on a bad way… this is some good shit… but I was expecting some crazy shit that was finally going to make me snap and go into a killing spree… but is just a good book about a serial killer pigeon doing some weird shit in NYC back in the days… it kind of feels like an American Psycho for Toddlers or something like that…

I loved this so frikin frackin much! Holden just might be my favourite fictional character of all time.I know majority of the people don't like it but I don't know man, everything Holden did and thought and said just felt so real. So brilliant!
Hated by phonies everywhere, this is a cult classic for anyone who's ever felt detached from the world (New Hampshire and batteries not included).
What the goddamn world needs now is yet another person to go on about 'The Catcher in the Rye'.

3.5 StarsHolden Caulfield is a lazy slacker in school. He doesn't want to apply himself to his classes and thinks everyone at Pencey Academy is a phony. After a fight with one of his roommates, he packs his bags and leaves.The school had kicked him out anyway because he flunked all of his classes besides English. He's got two days to kill till his parents expect him at home. What can a teenage, hormonal boy do but get drunk, attempt to flirt with older women, and, as Holden frequently puts it, horse around? May I be the millionth one to ask how in the world this ever became a classic? I suppose this is the gruesome birth of YA novels. It really surprised me how similar it was to how YA novels are written today. Imagine a John Green book, then put it together with The Perks of Being a Wallflower and this is the love child. I swear, it was like Stephan Chbosky read the book ten times and then wrote The Perks of Being a Wallflower. (although the writing style was actually much better in The Catcher in the Rye, if I'm honest) It was as if the author had gotten drunk, sat down, and wrote all night, and in the morning, The Catcher in the Rye was the result. Holden, besides being a compulsive liar, among other things, was a bit (understatement) mentally unstable. Everything depressed him and he thought about death all the time. He thought about how things would be if he died, how his family would react, the people who would show up at his funeral, etc. Then he'd turn around and say he didn't want to die or 'disappear'.Sometimes Holden would say something completely and utterly true as to how people think or what people do and act. Some of the things he thought were uncannily true/accurate observations of human nature. Then he'd say or think something that would be completely and utterly stupid and you'd think, what the hell, man? To Holden, everyone was either a phony, a moron, a whore, or just plain stupid. He was extremely judgmental. He judged people immediately on how they either looked or acted. But what people look like or even how they act is not necessarily a key to how they truly are. Maybe that's what the book was trying to say; how when you meet someone, you immediately make judgements about them. You can't help it, your mind does it almost automatically. That's what Holden represents, perhaps. I don't know. Maybe Holden was just kind of an asshole.Holden, to me, was an asshole, and at the same time, I kind of liked him. I pitied him. More or less. He was a depressed boy, and one who didn't know what to do with his life. Leaving school and being on his own for a few nights made him realize how depressing the world was when you looked at it. He felt like how a lot of teenagers do: that school is pointless and you feel invisible and just want to fit in. Everything's multiplied: Your hormones, your fatigue, your emotions, your judgements, etc. Small actions by others can set you off, either positively or negatively. The only thing I knew about this book before I went into it was that the main character's name was Holden. That's it. Now I know that it's about a boy named Holden who goes around smoking cigarettes, getting depressed, and being judgmental. Some parts of the book I really liked, and other parts irritated me, or were depressing. I have very mixed feelings about it. I really loved the second to last chapter, with Phoebe and Holden. What I didn't get was why Holden started getting angry with her all of the sudden when he got out of the museum. Why he felt such sudden hatred towards his little sister and even wanted to hit her. What the hell was that about?But my favorite scene came soon after that, when Phoebe put the hunting hat on Holden's head. It was so sweet. It's not a very pleasant book to read, I'll say that much. Holden is mentally and physically sick and his judgmental comments would be insulting to a lot of people. But then again, he's actually pretty funny sometimes. There were a couple nice sayings that were quoteworthy but it's still not much different a typical John Green novel nowadays. I'm guessing it was probably the inspiration for Green to write his books like he does. It's how the mainstream authors got started. It's one of those books that I liked and disliked at the same time. Very conflicting emotions. (view spoiler)[ I borrowed my copy from the library, and the book was written all over in the margins. But you know how Holden says 'goddamn' all the time? Well, someone had tried to cross out all the 'god' parts in 'goddamn'. Someone else erased the marks but you could still clearly tell what they had done. Lmao here. (hide spoiler)]

I have read this book ten times now and I am so emotional about it that I don't even know what to say, but it's amazing and I am never going to love anything ever in the world as much as this book because it is beautiful okay peace out.***Catcher is my number one, favourite book of all time. This time reading it I annotated and made notes through-out, and so instead of trying to write the review that I have spent years trying to articulate (and which will be majorly biased anyway), I thought I'd just share the things I picked up on from my ninth reading of this novel. - Reference to David Copperfield at the start both links it to and separates it from classic bildungsroman tales- Holden plays a classic childlike game of catch outside an academic building, only to be told by a teacher to stop. A symbol of the swelling pressure of academia and adulthood on his life.- The Egyptians are so important for a number of different reasons. Firstly, Holden is fascinated by them because of their ability to preserve bones, translating to his need to preserve the youth and innocence of others. Holden then 'teaches' this to two young boys in a museum near the end of the novel, symbolically becoming the role of the teacher himself and thus closing up the circle of innocence-to-experience that he comes to terms with by the end. - Holden is an extremely unreliable narrator, more unreliable than I first ever noticed. Sometimes it's to 'hoarse' around but other times it's to save his reputation, like when he says he only threw up after drinking because he 'made' himself throw up. As well as this being an obvious lie, it disconnects him from those he sees abusing alcohol and convinces us (badly) that he is not one of them.- To have sex is to 'give someone the time', perhaps because it's a sign of growing older and maturity. Represents a moving forward of time.- Dancing is linked to Phoebe which is then linked to innocence. He likes girls who can dance because he likes the feeling of happiness he gets from dancing with his little sister. It is a sigh of youth and freedom.- Only one person in the whole book asks him if he's on his own, and he completely avoids her question and doesn't answer. - The way he talks about women is objectifying, infantilising and vaguely rapey.- References to the war link the trauma of war to the corruption of innocence, such as when Holden won't let Allie play with his BB guns because they are a symbol of violence. He constantly pretends he's been shot in a movie whenever he is hurt to deter from the realism of the war, and though he recognises how damaging this is, he continues to do it for his own protection.- So much is said about class, especially when talking about the guy who used his suitcases, and the visions he has of Sally drinking tea with the Lunts and the Ivy League boys. He hates it, although he is part of that culture himself.- Holden really doesn't like Romeo and Juliet because they did dumb shit when they tried to grow up too fast.- Harris Macklin is the opposite to Stradlater.- Holden takes Sally's hand when he wants to run away with her because he used to do that with Jane, and he's trying to reclaim those feelings- He sees no ducks in the park when he finally gets there because every other duck has flown away apart from him, leaving him in his own bubble of self denial and isolation.- There is a link between when James Castle commits suicide and when Holden contemplates suicide at the hotel. Holden is worried that nobody will cover up his body like Antolini did for James because he doesn't believe that the adults around him are capable of the good that Antolini is. - The 'fall' that Antolini talks about to Holden is the fall into adulthood.- Holden dreams of going into an isolated cabin to live his perfect life which is weirdly the exact same thing that Salinger did.- The mention of the 'psychoanalyst' at the end convinces me that Holden is in fact an a mental institution rather than being treated at a hospital for TB, which is what many speculate. He states that he 'practically' got TB, not that he actually got it, and we would be wise to distrust Holden when he uses such slippery language.

Depressed, disoriented, displaced, and later, you learn that he is also traumatized. So goes Salinger's teenaged protagonist, Holden. When he tells you in the beginning that he doesn't want to talk about his "lousy childhood" and how his "parents were occupied" before they had him, be thankful that he told you at least that because Holden doesn't seem to like talking about what's bothering him. He will, however, tell you about everyone else. It helps that at first glance, Holden commands your attention. This is where Salinger's mastery of character-voice is spellbinding, he seems to enjoy toying with stream of consciousness, seamlessly veering between first and second point of views, to create fiction in opposition of boarding schools, much like Orwell did in his nonfiction essay, Such, Such Were The Joys.Holden is disappointed in human behavior: You should've seen the way he did with my roommate's parents. I mean if a boy's mother was sort of fat or corny-looking or something, and if somebody's father was one of those guys that wear those suits with very big shoulders and corny black-and-white shoes, then old Haas would just shake hands with them and give them a phony smile and then he'd go talk, for maybe a half an hour, with somebody else's parents. I can't stand that stuff. It drives me crazy. It makes me so depressed.From there on, we enter Holden's depression. And you see why the protagonist is a young boy. The rant would not have worked for an adult because, as we know, the teenage mind is an enigma. Yes, teenagers can get away with such rueful raves. This teenager is the son of absent parents: a hard-working but distant lawyer-father, and a semi-reclusive mother. His older brother is a famous writer, his other brother is deceased (and you can tell that this really bothers him) and he simply adores his little sister, Phoebe. So what's the problem? Well, you don't get snippets until later in the book. But back to Holden's depression, because he makes you aware of it throughout the book. This is one instance where showing versus telling in literary fiction, is done with equal measure. Eighty pages in: Holden is too depressed to care whether he had a good view or not in his hotel room (you heard correctly, this teeanager manages to purchase booze and hotel rooms and all). Ninety eight pages in: Radio City Music Hall makes Holden so depressed, he just can't stand it. One hundred and six pages in: "New York's terrible when somebody laughs on the street very late at night. You can hear it for miles. It makes you feel so lonesome and depressed."Lots of opinions, that Holden. He is a virgin who somehow has procured knowledge about women. And just because he doesn't do his schoolwork, don't think that he doesn't read. In fact, he will tell you how considers A Farewell to Arms a phony book, but he is crazy about The Great Gatsby .Almost two hundred pages in, and I thought something was going to happen. Really, I did. Phoebe intervenes and you really start to see Holden because through their dialogue, she's telling us some things. Afterwards, when his former teacher, Mr. Antolini intervenes, my hopes are really up because maybe this is turning into a lesson after all, especially since the teacher gives Holden the "many, many men have been just as troubled morally and spiritually as you are right now...you'll learn from them" speech. Then boom, my hopes are smashed when Holden thinks Mr. Antolini is being--well, you know. The trauma from seeing another kid die in such a horrific way, plus the trauma that comes from people always being "perverty" around him in boarding school, makes you understand why Holden is so depressed. But the idea that there is not enough of a setup to allow you to really see him clearly (in fact it's easy to miss the important details) is also depressing. Not to mention the fact that there is no silver lining at the end.Sigh. Now I'm a bit depressed. *3.5 stars*

"Don't ever tell anybody anything. If you do, you start missing everybody." God I love this book.First of all it's kind of hard to explain why I love Catcher in the Rye since my reasons are highly personal and I was not even in the mood explaining some of my past life experiences just for you to understand why I felt such great connection and empathy with Holden Caufield. Just put it this way that once in my teenage life I've experienced alienation and depression. It was painful and it really made me sad and depressed that through this novel I was able to remember those things that I really don't want to even remember.See I am depressed. This book made me depressed.It just made me realized some things like when maybe sometime in the future you'll meet someone, a person who doesn't have anyone to talk to, it is important that you listen to them, just listen, and maybe that was enough for them. Sometimes this world and this life is such a sad place to live in but if you know that there is someone willing to stay with you or be your friend, it doesn't seem so sad anymore.More Things I like about it:1. It was an easy read, even if it's a Classic book surprisingly it was very easy to read unlike Pride and Prejudice and The Great Gatsby (note: I didn't even finish these two books because my head exploded while I was reading them).2. It was very similar to The New Dress by Virginia Woolf and what a surprise they even have the same "stream of consciousness" style and the "non-linear plot" style. Mind you I love The New Dress but Catcher in the Rye was way better.3. Symbolism:

-ducks= was actually Holden Caufield***When Holden Caufield was asking the cab driver what will happen to the ducks in the pond during Winter. What he was actually trying to say is that: "What will happen to me during this winter?"-red hunting hat= security blanket-when Holden says "You" in the narrative he actually means "I"One Thing I Don't Like About It1. The book was very "Anti-Girl" I just didn't like it that Holden says so many negative things about women and that he really generalizes women. Like for example he had an experience with this girl and he'll say something negative about it and then after that he will generalize it that "All girls are like that" and that was really way over the belt and that's just faulty generalization. I am a girl and all the negative things mention in this book about "girls in general" were highly ridiculous and so not true.Book Reviews by John Green, themissingn and 60 second recap ***I recommend you to watch these if you wanna understand Catcher in the Rye deeply***John Green:http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZSR8J6...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kqfThm...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QUnQ-w...themissingnhttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j3iHnu...60 second recaphttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=reoZoK...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k4qlN0...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wr9_N9...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mHS_kT...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jI0MJE...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mtO5RH...http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nx3FF1...PS: This book made me want to kill John Lennon *kidding*

You can read more of my reviews at Queen of ContemporaryI don’t usually read classics. I’m not sure why. For some reason, classics are totally different to other books and scare me off. So when I was assigned to read this for school, I was a bit skeptical. After all, it is one of the ‘great American classics.’ The thing is, though, I ended up really, really loving it. It’s now one of my favourite books of all time.To explain the plot is quite hard because there isn’t really a plot at all. The Catcher in the Rye is very character driven, almost entirely character driven. We get hints of a core plot running through the entire novel, but, even at the end, and after thinking very hard, I’m still not entirely sure of the plot. I think you just need to pick it up and read for yourself.Our protagonist is Holden Caulfield. At the start of the novel we find out he has been kicked out of his fourth school, Pencey Prep. After a string of events meaning Holden leaves Pencey days before he is supposed to, he finds himself in New York.The Catcher in the Rye is a story of adolescence and identity. Holden often talks of adults being ‘phonies’ and has a very childlike mind. Throughout the novel we get the idea that Holden is grasping onto the last threads of his childhood whilst coming to terms with his impending adulthood. It’s such a difficult time and age is something that is mentioned a lot during the novel, whether it’s Holden being told he’s too young to drink in a bar, or calling someone ‘old.’ The contrast between young and old is striking and I think it’s very interesting to think about.Another major theme is acceptance. Through his actions, it is clear that Holden is seeking the acceptance and attention he so needs. It’s as if he needs the bridge between childhood and adulthood to be acknowledged.Holden is such an interesting and inspiring character. I felt as if I understood him to such a great extent and his words were so thought provoking. Salinger has created a character that is the epitome of teenage thoughts and feelings. Teenage years are full of discovering who you are, and Holden’s journey was all about discovering himself. I really wanted to give him a big hug.The Catcher in the Rye isn’t the right book for everyone, but you won’t know until you try it out.

Alright.I've read quite a few books in my lifetime thus far; enough to believe that I have a hold on what constitutes as good literature and what does not. Books are one of the greatest passions in my life, and I have utmost respect for authors. I never, ever want to hate a piece of literature, especially one that has had such a tremendous impact on the greater culture.However. I can't help it here. The Catcher in the Rye is one of the worst books I have ever picked up and read. And I can honestly say that I did genuinely read it, cover to cover. Its popularity and praise baffles me to no end, and the fact that so many angsty adolescents swear to identify with Holden is even more baffling. Holden whines for two-hundred pages about life, love, and his abhorrence for fake, conformist idiots. It blows my mind how three-quarters of the readers who claim to be Holden's kindred spirit are those exact idiots he just spent an entire twenty-six chapters detesting.The plot of the story...wait, what plot? The entire book is one giant, boring, continuous narrative that circles around endlessly in Caufield's head. Let's put it this way. If you were feeling particularly pretentious and moody one day, and you went on a walk to clear your head, the spiteful, mouthy ramblings of your conscience would be on par with what this book is essentially all about. To be blunt, Salinger; no one cares.
