If I wanted to read two-hundred pages of some over-priveleged youth complaining about anything and everything for no legitimate reason, I'd pick up my old high school diary. I have found that most of the people who truly enjoy this book aren't die-hard readers. Now, that may be a completely personal experience, and if it is, I do apologize. My best friend, who is just as much if not more of a bookworm than I am, does nothing but close her eyes and shake her head in disappointment at the mention of The Catcher in the Rye.Read this book at your own risk. Chances are, you will either fall completely in love with it or you will hate it with a fiery passion. I was of the latter, quite obviously. I simply did not, do not get it.

Teen angst is a glorious thing. I can remember going through that part of my life and I cringe looking back at certain moments when I let those emotions/feelings dictate something I said or did. It’s not that they don’t hold value but that the person is acting upon them immediately and in an over the top way. As you get older you learn to blunt the sharp edges of those feelings and let them simmer more before acting upon them. You also learn to vent better by talking them out or writing them down (to name a few), so you can see the root of the issue and understand why you are reacting the way you are.This is the story of a boy that is letting every emotion and feeling he has immediately guide every decision he makes. If school sucks you quit, if your family doesn’t understand you run away, if your friend goes on a date with the girl you like you pick a fight with him. He isn’t allowing any time to review those feelings and to understand better why he is feeling them. Everything he feels is unique to only him and everything he does is in the moment. I completely understand that this is common behavior for that age range (I was guilty of it myself) and I am not knocking Holden for it. I’m sure I will look back in twenty years at my current self and cringe for a whole new set of reasons with the midlife crisis phase of my life being right around the corner. From the reader’s perspective you are inside of Holden’s head listening to his side of it all and at first it is quite an interesting voice. It doesn’t take long for that interest to wane and for his voice to drift into nails on a chalkboard territory. It’s like whatever made the writing style unique and amazing at first didn’t last throughout the rest of the book. A few chapters in and I could have started skipping paragraphs and/or chapters and I would not have lost the plot at all. It was just him internally rationalizing his self-destructive behavior and not understanding why the results of that behavior was happening to him. You can like a book for different reasons such as writing style/voice, characters, story and how it made you feel, and I could not check any of those boxes for this book.

Holden is kind of a mood, “I'm quite illiterate, but I read a lot.” Ha same here kid.Holden chronic loneliness and his self-sabotaging thoughts and/or behaviour is well depicted. How he manages his contradicting thought processes and life's pressures did hit home. For some reason, these 200 odd pages felt much longer. This slice of life vibe is pretty hit and miss for me and I would've liked a little more closure in terms of Holden's plans, next steps vis à vis his mental health etc. But I do get that the whole point was his lack of direction and inability to make coherent decisions. Perhaps I'm simply too small-brained to fully appreciate this book...That said there were definitely a couple of gems that jumped out to me. One being that I've never related more to a sentiment that I do: "If somebody knows quite a lot about [the theatre, plays and literature], it takes you quite a while to find out whether they're really stupid or not." Well said Holden. I loved how he explores and categorises intelligence and what he deemed stimulating conversation. As an active avoider of small talk myself, this did make me chuckle. You really get the vibe that he's an old soul in a young body and I admire how well Salinger portrays that.Mr Anyolini is quite the character, I really liked his worldly view and his notion that one should find "what size mind you have and what it will and won't fit in it" and while he had some questionable moments, (view spoiler)[like what the heck was going on with that midnight head petting? Was that him being an eccentric fatherly figure? Or was Holden right in his reaction and quick escape? (hide spoiler)] how quickly he offered Holden a place to crash and some parental wisdom tugged at my heartstrings.

5/5Holden Caulfield is like Marmite; you either love it or hate it. For the time being, I inevitably fall into the first category. Holden is the perfect example of the conflicted rebel without a cause; an hypocritical, cynical complainer. But there is a also decadent innocence inherent to him, a twist that without trying makes him incredibly realistic and likeable for me. His is not a regular coming of age tale in which the character's view of the world changes from child to adult. Holden instead finds himself trapped between these two perspectives, and their friction has as a result a feeling of being lost and misunderstood which is reflected by his thoughts throughout this short novel.Salinger made Holden's demeanour ridiculously enjoyable and interesting for me. I loved his one liners and the in absentia figure of Jane through the book - the fact that we never get to see her contemporary self is a nice, unexpected touch. This book won't work for you if you're not into character development as it is ultimately more of a description of a boy's personality than it is a story per se. That being said, if this is your thing please give it a chance. Wish there were more books like this nowadays rather than having to fall into the same silly plot twists every time.

All i understand from this book is that kid can't adapt to the world of faking adults. This explains his fascination with children and how he is always willing to help them. He wants to maintain his connection with the grownups but they are hypocrites and make him depressed. He wants real talk and genuine conversations but they seem to seek the material things like sex and money. He wants his brother to write real literature not phony movies in Hollywood. But his soft soul is not so strong for this harsh world.The protagonist deals with a trauma because of his brother's death. And it shows us the bond of brotherhood. Also,the there is a special friendship between him and his little sister who seems to have an effect on his life. The book is a slow read and requires patience, especially that it makes use of repetitive vocabulary and sentences. But i get the idea that it is written from o teenager's point of view. A thing that maybe was not that common in literature. Now it is not that extraordinary because we have a plethora of Y/A novels written about adolescents and their provlems and their mental health. I gave it this bunch of stars because it has a little sweet girl that somehow saves her brother.And because of the feeling you get when you discover the meaning of book title.

Hm.. very neutral feelings on this one. I thought I would enjoy this more than I did. I sort of had a predetermined opinion on this, I think? Since it's such a popular classic and I grew up knowing it's basic premise, I thought I would relate to Holden much more than I did. He's 17 in this, and having turned 18 only at the end of last year, I thought I would see myself in Holden like so many others have, but I found myself annoyed with his narration more than anything. I liked the repetitiveness and pretentiousness in the beginning, but after about 50 pages I'd had enough. Holden is insufferable, though I can't really blame him. He calls out everything wrong with his surroundings, without focusing on the good, and after being in his head for a while I started to feel negatively towards him and everything he was describing. I guess I would have enjoyed this more if I had read this in high school, either for a class or for fun. I think this could be an interesting read if you're spending time analysing and critiquing the book in an academic sense, but this unfortunately didn't really do much for me.

Holden Caulfield is the kind of bastard that can't enjoy art if he finds the artist conceited. He's the kind of bastard that easily identifies the pettiness of others but grows lonely when deprived of their company. He's the kind of bastard that lies to ease conversation, flunks school for high-minded reasons he can't articulate, and flings his last pennies across a lake in an attempt to assuage his melancholy. Holden Caulfield is among the most harmless and entertaining of all bastards; he is a silly bastard.Many readers don't like Holden and a great deal of the analysis of this novel focuses on our protagonist's childishness and selfishness. But I find Holden a model of mixed-up compassion. He sees people's warts because he cares enough to look, and he appreciates other people enough to miss them when they're not around. He can spot a phony a mile away and this fuels his gloomy outlook; part of him realizes that he's as mixed-up and phony as everyone else. Holden's dilemma is a timeless one; no one likes a faker, but we all wear masks sometimes.Edited 8/1/2020

This book really surprised me for how poor it was. I even read a few analysis texts after I finished it to see if I'd missed anything. I understand the point the author was trying to make with Holden's character - the archetype of the rebel, nihilistic adolescent. I don't agree with reviews that say that "if you didn't like this book it's because you don't understand/relate to Holden" - I think most people who've been through their teens can relate to him. But this book was just incessant complaining about everything and everyone and I really don't feel like it added anything positive to me. I just wanted it to end asap because this style of writing really annoyed me.Although I understand what Salinger was trying to represent, I just don't feel like that's enough to create a compelling/good story.The only parts that made me care about the story was any passage where Holden talked about his little siblings - the only people he seems to truly care about - but even that didn't feel like it was properly explored.

"What really knocks me out is a book that, when you're all done reading it, you wish the author that wrote it was a terrific friend of yours and you could call him up on the phone whenever you felt like it. That doesn't happen much, though."Boy, did I feel the same way after I was done reading this.So, this novel was totally pointless. It had no plot, and it felt like J. D. Salinger had written every chapter without any forethought whatsoever, and let Holden do what he may. How about the whole Jane thing? Did Holden never call her because he was never in the mood to do so, or because Salinger wasn't in the mood to write any such scene? Holden himself, for all his posturing, was the biggest phony of the lot. Somehow, despite all the above (or perhaps because of it), I enjoyed this novel tremendously. It killed me. It really did. I still haven't figured out why, though. If I ever do, I will definitely tell you.

The story of a boy kicked out of a school full of 'phonies': the students are rich, 'morons' and 'crooks' ("the more expensive a school is, the more crooks it has"), the professors are unable to understand 'what's the matter' with this young boy Caulfield Holden. So, Holden decides to run away and spend the days before Christmas holiday in a creepy hotel in New York where he meets 'lousy people' and feels 'damn lonely'. He tries to understand 'where the ducks go during the winter', but the question seems to be quite inappropriate. He has only a dream: being 'the catcher of all the kids in a rye', being the only adult looking at them playing in the field and rescue them if they go over the cliff. At the end, his sister will rescue him. While it is bucketing down, he will feel 'damn happy' looking at her going around and around on the carousel. And you will laugh and cry, because the whole story is quite ironical and tragic 'and all'.

So...I know this is a supposed classic and it sooo great and blah blah blah pffft. But, I hated it. I don't know if it's because I didn't read it in high school like everyone else but read it later in life when I just wanted this whiny spoiled rich kid to shutttt upppppp. I also didn't care for the writing style - some my call it simple prose, I call it crap that my cat could write (and probably would. My cat has a similar sense of entitlement to that of Holden Caulfiend - oops, I mean Caulfield) Now, I try not to let this influence my opinion of J.D. salinger's other celebrated work as I have not yet read anything else by him and I hear Frannie and Zooey is amazing. So, yeah, there you have it. Didn't like Catcher in the Rye, so sue me.

I was conflicted on whether to rate this 2 or 3 stars but I went with 2 because ultimately, this book really bored me. This book was 234 pages long, and the pages were small, and it took me more than a week to finish this book. I just never enjoyed picking this book up and reading it, This was a book I had to read for school and I just found it very boring and kind of pointless. I know a lot of people love this book and a lot of people hate it and I get that. I am not able to see the genius of this book or the meaning in the subtext or whatever makes this book incredible to other people. When I was 16 I don't think I every hated everything like Holden Caulfield did. Ultimately, I can kind of get how this book can have a lot of people that love it, but I just didn't enjoy it.

Okay I am ducking in advance, expecting a shoe to be thrown at me. I had heard such good things about this book and how great it was. It was a good book, don't get me wrong, but it wasn't as profound as people led me to think it was. I liked the voice of the protagonist. He was fearless in the things he thought, did, and said. He was searching, and didn't find by the end of the book, but he was okay with who he was. I thought that was cool. However this book didn't change my life or give me the key to meaning. But it was a good way to fill some hours out of my life. As far as coming of age books, I think To Kill a Mockingbird is much better.

I didn’t enjoy it. The writing is all over the place, and perhaps J.D. Salinger wrote it that way intentionally, but it didn’t make it very interesting, and honestly made it slightly confusing at points. I didn’t like Holden Caulfield that much, and his habit of calling everything “depressing” or “phony” was annoying to me. I think my dislike of the main character is the main reason I didn’t like the book, but I did like the whole crisis of identity part (and Phoebe). Maybe I’ll read it in fifty years and be astonished I disliked it in the past, but for now I do not regard it as a good book, and I don’t think I’ll be suggesting it to anyone.

3 stars - It was good.-------------------------------------------Favorite Quote: Make sure you marry someone who laughs at the same things you do.First Sentence: If you really want to hear about it, the first thing you'll probably want to know is where I was born, and what my lousy childhood was like, and how my parents were occupied and all before they had me, and all that David Copperfield kind of crap, but I don't feel like going into it, if you want to know the truth.

I enjoyed the book, simply for enjoyment's sake. Why it's such a cult classic and has such an extreme cult following, I don't quite understand. But, I am a sucker for self depreciation in books as well as some deep internal reflection... Books like that speak to me since I am so deeply analytical. This book was no exception. I think everyone should probably read this story once, if only to be able to participate in discussions when the topic arises!

“It's funny. All you have to do is say something nobody understands and they'll do practically anything you want them to.” ― J.D. Salinger, The Catcher in the RyeThis novel is a masterpiece . I really liked every chapter . Holden Caulfield is - by far - my favorite charachter ! and I'm sure that there won't be someone like Holden ever again ; a very strong and an ICONIC charachter . i just love it the book .

I know it’s weird to rate one of your favorite books 4/5 stars, but I don’t think this book is perfect. There are parts of this book I find boring and other parts I find really emotional and beautiful. I don’t really know what else to say, this book made me feel a lot of feelings.
Pivotal novel. A must for anyone whose ever felt alienation or all those lovely teenager feelings.
this book was terrible...that's all i really have to say

I view The Catcher in the Rye as a difficult and complicated book to review. Not because it's a difficult or overly complicated book; it's not. But, because this book is read through so many different lenses, taught by so many different types of teachers in school and interpreted in so many different types of ways, it has become an object of visceral reaction (or something people merely scratch their head about wondering what all the fuss is about). Simply put, this is one of the best selling novels of all time and has remained a hot commodity (averaging about 250,000 copies a year). With so many people reading this book, with so much academic emphasis placed upon it, and with persistent conversation about the book over time, it has simply become difficult to establish order in the chaos. Some people go so far as to consider this book a brand, and will try and categorize (one way or the other) people based on whether or not someone likes this book. So what's the deal? Well let's explore a couple of the different ways someone might "get something" out of this novel:It seems the predominant view of this book is that it is essentially a novel of teen angst. That it deals with the issues of having to grow up, give up your childhood, and find our place in the big, scary, uncertain world. This view might also claim the book deals with issues of belonging, alienation, and some identity issues. From what I've seen, people who subscribe to this interpretation of the novel are also likely to claim that they identify with Holden Caulfield (the main character from whose point of view the book is written). That they get him, or perhaps more accurately, that Holden Caulfield gets the reader. Some people who do not hold this book in high regard often arrive at the same interpretation, but take the opposite position. They claim that Holden Caulfield is a whiny brat. That he needs to just get over his problems, grow up, and stop being so annoying. Now, I'm not particularly qualified to tell someone what a book is or is not about, and if someone wants claim that one of the above descriptions is an accurate portrayal of the book, then I can't exactly tell them that they're wrong. But I sort of think it. Perhaps not so much that they're wrong, but that they aren't entirely accurate. You see, I believe it's a drastic error to think that this book was written for the reader. I think this book isn't written for us, it's written for J.D. Salinger, and it just happens to be published so we can read it. What I mean by that, is that the author of this book is inseparable from the novel itself. J.D. Salinger was drafted into the army for World War 2, and fought in Europe, from Normandy to Berlin until the end of the war. He participated in D-Day, The battle of the Bulge, Bastogne, and countless other horrific engagements. He was also one of the first Americans to enter and liberate a Nazi concentration camp. He told his daughter once that "You never really get the smell of burning flesh out of your nose entirely, no matter how long you live." It's no large stretch of anyone's imagination to say that J.D. Salinger was suffering, deeply, from PTSD. So let's look back on Holden Caulfield. A teenager who seems unable to move on with his life. He saw (view spoiler)[a classmate commit a violent suicide while wearing an article of Holden's clothing (hide spoiler)]. And let's not forget Holden's most important source of trauma (view spoiler)[his little brother Allie, whose death he blames himself for (hide spoiler)]. The big sort of "reveal" at the end is that (view spoiler)[Holden is telling the whole story to a doctor within the walls of a mental institution (hide spoiler)]. Does Holden Caulfield behave the way he does in the novel because he's some angsty teen who feels uncertain about his future, or does he behave the way he does because he's a teenager suffering from Post-Traumatic Stress? After The Catcher in the Rye was published, J.D. Salinger quickly became a recluse and withdrew from public life. I can imagine why. He writes a novel that is the manifestation of his way of trying to work through unimaginable trauma, and in return he gets middle-class teenagers saying, "That's just like me! I know what he's going through!" That may be true for a very small percentage of readers, but for most of us we simply don't. Now, if someone wants to like the book because it "speaks" to them, or because it deals with some issues that they can connect with, then that's great! I'll almost always applaud when someone finds a new book they love, and I'm not trying to dismiss other people who either like or do not like this novel.I simply think it's particularly important to keep context in mind when talking (or disagreeing) about this book. I obviously do have a higher opinion of this novel, since I rated it 5-stars, but I have a high opinion of the novel because it reveals to me some interesting ways in how the human mind works. I find I can respect Salinger for writing a book that was so personal to him, and I enjoy romping through a true war-veteran's portrayal of a boy who lost his innocence and is trying to make sense of the world and people around him. Holden's narrative is often flavorless, his descriptions minute, unfair, and childish. Yet, that's the point. Holden focuses on the unimportant things about people and life, gives them a meaning that is blown out of proportion, and snags himself on these small details. Why? Because it's a coping mechanism that prevents him from dealing with the things that truly matter. He uses the term phony throughout the book. Why is everything phony? Because reality is too painful. Bottom line? I enjoy this book. I think there's a surprising amount of meat to chew on, for it being such a quick read. Some people might say, "Oh, there's THAT guy. He's one of those who like The Catcher in the Rye. He's one of THOSE types of people." But frankly, that's fine. I don't like this book because I'm trying to make some emotional statement. I just simply like it. Is it the best book ever? Of course not. But I dig it for what it is, and I think everyone should give it a fair chance.

Hm... I liked it better second time around but I'm sticking with three stars. When a book is this praised and also notorious(?) it's difficult to gauge my personal reflections.I sympathised a lot with Holden. Almost every page is dripping with boredom, directionlessness and alienation. Particular how uncomfortable it makes others when he wants them to listen to his feelings: even fine well knowing he might not mean what he says even a few minutes later, no one can take it. He is passive aggressively “trained” into either saying nothing or exactly what someone else wants to hear. The only times he’s allowed to speak his mind at length are when he elaborates upon what he knows is exactly what the other person wants to hear, even arguing in one case, while lying to a mother about her son on the train, that she would lack so much perspective on her own son as to believe Holden’s lies forever. It’s no wonder Holden is unable to interpret his actions with no one to talk to.Post-war New York is a place in time that likely fully embraced comfort, safety, routine, and banal pleasantry, until, in Holden’s eyes, citizens became babyish phonies incapable of real interaction. The part at the end about Holden’s little sister seems to be about the perpetual production of innocence and those who will always question trivial societal structures, etiquettes and habits. Holden spends most of his time talking to adults and those who idolize adults (actors and the upper class), and given that this novel was originally intended for an adult audience, do we see Holden as representative of the coming generation to highlight the responsibilities of the adult generation to the next one down, and the harm of all their fearful fakery? Holden opts for the possibility offered by children over the rigid formalities of adults: he hopes for change.I’ve been a proper out-of-uni adult for about 2 years now and heavily steeped in all the banal status-and-banter constructs of the brainless, so I get Holden’s fears about what will happen to him when he grows up. Why wouldn’t they come true? I don’t know.I can also see why this is popular amongst alienated teen folk but I think a lot of the insights had to have been made by an adult for an adult. (Likely an English teacher will find this in two years and write back to me as if I just wrote this, at which point I’ll probably think something else! Also I’m really happy for you but Iain Banks penned the best teen angst stuff of all time!) Holden is an unreliable narrator who cannot fully articulate what his confessions are doing, which I believe is to draw together a collective mentality of reaction to the zeitgeist. He is prone to surface observations and hyperbole. He feels often that his problems are his and his alone and that nobody gets him and everyone else is fake. Loner “killers” perhaps attach themselves to his view as truth: “Me and you, Holden, me and you, and no one else!” whereas the book’s popularity is testament to many people feeling like Holden. We can be many people feeling like the only ones, but we can’t all be the only ones. To say that his angst is just a phase is kinda stupid. It may be aggravated by teenage years but it is brought about by the environment rather than Holden himself who is not inarticulate nor unintelligent. That environment still exists today. Maybe always will…Anyways, I consider myself an open guy who’s willing to discuss anything with anyone. But I’ve also perpetuated the illusion of society’s wall of artifice: say someone I don’t know very well skips a few steps in the normal social constructs of getting to know me and stands too close and does the “Don’t you just think that everyone” etcetera, you know the type, well, I’ll sigh and bat them away because their thoughts to me will be shallow and repetitious and maybe I was having a good time and don’t wanna get into it, whereas this guy will walk away thinking that his attitude has been confirmed, that he’s him and I’m one of them. Maybe I was tired. Maybe I’d had that same conversation recently with someone else and didn’t feel like having it again so soon. Maybe I was really tired. Maybe if I had more time and I knew the guy better I’d listen. Or if I thought he’d read up about his ideas even in the slightest so he could be a bit objective. Or if I didn’t suspect (or know, most times) that he had other people in his network to rant at or others that he had ranted at word-for-word the same, and didn’t feel like wasting my time helping someone who was being helped. I can forgive myself for this every now and then: after all, I’m only human and as much as I believe in the curative properties of empathy and compassion, I know them to be very slowly-renewable resources that are best conserved. But there’s only so many times I can be like that before it becomes dangerous: someone has to listen. I don’t think anyone listened to Holden; I don’t know that anyone eventually did; and I don’t know what became of him as a result.I’m more than sure all of the above has been produced by deconstruction after deconstruction of this novel but I’m not gonna read any of that, so there :DOriginal review below, which still stands:Salinger sucks.Caulfield sucks.Rye sucks.Yeah?Life sucks.You suck.I suck.Waaaaaaaaaaaah

I’ll confess that when I first read this, I wasn’t quite sure what to make of it. I don’t always catch the analogies hidden beneath the surface or the social implications of what the book could be about. All I knew was this was on the classics list, I hadn’t read it, and it was one of the most banned books in history, based on language, violence, promiscuity, and the threat of encouraging moral decay. The book is about a young teenage boy named Holden who gets kicked out of many schools. It’s all about him and his rebellion at everything. It’s said that it’s an analogy for growing up. All I saw was a teenager who saw through a lot of people’s bullshit and walked away depressed because of it. He expressed himself as most teenagers of his time, granting Salinger a comment in excellence at his portrayal of a young boy’s angst. But other than that, I can’t say it moved me too much. After mulling it over for awhile, I think there were some themes dealing with a coming of age and lost innocence. I could see that in his dream, he was seeing himself leaving childhood and becoming the much dreaded adult. I also saw some of where Holden spoke much of what he didn't like in people that could probably be construed as racist. In today's politically correct world I can see how that would rub people the wrong way. I'm a big fan of telling it like it is and I think his honesty at his prejudices make him a deeper more developed character. I heard a quote once that said, "You show me a man who's not prejudice, and I'll show you a really good liar. - Anonymous" I completely agree. I also often agreed with young Holden in his views of how “phony” people could be, especially when he comments how when a girl he doesn’t like asks him to join her at her table in a bar, he’s forced to join her or leave…and thinks how often people just “mess stuff up for you”. He was irritated because he had to leave. Over all, I can’t say it was a page turner, but I would have to recommend it for the sheer fact that it was banned so many times and has become so controversial. I believe there are much more controversial books out there and it never ceases to amaze me which the general public tend to focus on. I also believe that the social and historical context of a book needs to be looked at when evaluating whether or not it should be a classic. I think for the time period of when this book came out, it was very controversial and prompted people to fight against the system, especially the young, which was another reason why it was probably banned. Due to the underlying themes, unique style of writing, the fact that it has a huge following, and that it is so controversial, I label it a classic as well. It takes time to appreciate some books some time, but perseverance always allows the greatness of a story to shine through.  ClassicsDefined.com

The Catcher in the Rye often evokes a passionate reaction when mentioned. Some people feel it fails to meet the expectations generated by the mystique it is shrouded in or they dislike the whining, self-obsessed protagonist. Others love everything about it. I fall into that latter category. However you feel about it, there is little doubt that The Catcher in the Rye effectively captures the reality of being a teenager with haunting accuracy and articulates so well what it feels like to be that awkward age between childhood and adulthood. It was published at a time when young adult fiction didn't really exist, so that in itself spoke to teenagers at that time. It also had - and continues to have - mass appeal: published in the lead up to the Civil Rights Movement, Holden became an icon of teenage rebellion for disaffected youth, and throughout history (even in the wake of Trump's Presidential election) young people have turned to the novel for understanding. Part of the beauty and the popularity of this book is that Holden's teenage angst speaks to everybody. It has been called "The Great American Novel" but I think it should be called "The Great Teenage Novel", because while not all of us are American, all of us have been teenagers. The Catcher in the Rye opens with seventeen-year-old Holden Caulfield residing in an unspecified institution in Southern California in either 1949 or 1950. The story unfolds as Holden recalls the events of the previous Christmas, after he was expelled from Pencey Preparatory Academy, a boarding school in Pennsylvania, owing to his unsatisfactory academic performance. The novels moves on to follow Holden on his perambulations around New York city that December as he attempts to find those few genuine people and true human connection.The novel was originally intended by Salinger for an adult readership, but Holden’s intense personal tale of his experiences amid the 'phoneys' of society has appealed to generations of adolescents ever since. Holden's stream of consciousness first-person narrative follows his exact thought processes so makes for a very intimate reading that not only speaks directly to the heart but to every generation of teenager, affirming that frustrated adolescents are not alone.The Catcher in the Rye addresses themes of identity, belonging, loss, connection, parental ignorance and sex, but most notably it is a story about the protection of innocence, especially of children, and the struggle of growing up; of that often painful transition from the comfortable and protected chrysalis of childhood to the unfamiliar and daunting reality of adolescence. I adore this book: it was one of the first novels to really speak to me as a young teenager and it will always have a very special place in my heart.

Praise the Giant Flying Spaghetti Monster, the pain is over.This book has been on my radar for years. I think the first time I heard about it was that Mel Gibson and Julia Roberts movie, Conspiracy Theory, in which Gibson's character can't calm down unless he has a copy of it, and in which the government apparently uses library patron histories to identify serial killers based on who borrows The Catcher in the Rye. Or something?? I haven't seen that movie in years, so I may be wrong.Anyway, I put off reading this book for YEARS because a tiny part of my brain was convinced that if I borrowed it from my local library, I'd be flagged as a serial killer. But basically, all I knew about the book was that the main character is called Holden Caulfield, and it's J.D. Salinger's only novel.And I kind of wish I'd left it that way. I was on the struggle bus with this book essentially from the get go. The opening few chapters - the stuff before Holden leaves school - reminded me a lot of Dead Poets Society, and more specifically Charlie. Seeing as Dead Poets Society is one of my favourite movies, I was moderately interested in the story.But then Holden left school, and things went rapidly downhill. We're trapped in Holden's head for endless pages with few other characters to break things up. And this was hard for me, because I didn't like Holden AT ALL. He's full of rich white boy problems, where everything is someone else's fault. Holden always thinks he's in the right, despite however much evidence is stacked up against him. Essentially, I couldn't stand him or the narrative style.I REALLY didn't like the writing. Admittedly, it's a product of the time. It's set in the late 1940s and is told by a teenage boy, so the amount of misogyny that comes through in the story is almost to be expected. But the amount of repetition in the writing drove me up the wall. Holden will make an observation about another character, then insert an anecdote about that character doing the thing he observed them doing, then repeat his observation. Like, "The girl could dance. [Insert long winded anecdote about said girl dancing here] I tell you, the girl could dance."YES. WE KNOW. YOU LITERALLY JUST TOLD US.By the end of the book, I just flat out didn't care, and when it featured a total non-ending on top of all the repetition and angst and misogyny that I'd already had to wade through, I was tempted to throw the book across the room.I feel like this is a book that's more enjoyable if a) you study it in school and can unpackage all the things that Salinger is trying to say, or b) you're an angsty teenager when you read it. So maybe if I'd read this as a teenager, I'd see the appeal. But as an adult? NOPE.

Dear Kris,I am glad you made me finish The Catcher in the Rye. I acknowledge, it is a classic. I don't understand why it is a classic, but it is. So it is probably a good thing I finally read it.Probably.It is a classic like Wuthering Heights. Which is to say, you English majors probably decided it was a classic and the rest of us bookworms decided to read it. And if Goodreads is anything to go by, a lot of people are glad they did. I didn't hate this book like I hated Flowers for Algernon. I think The Catcher in the Rye has some merit. I love the opening lines. It is one of the best hooks I have read in a long time. The book certainly presents a...unique hero. I don't care much for angst, though. I recognize that there were some moving, powerful scenes. I recognize that Holden is a very broken kid. I recognize that this book was well-written in how horribly written it is. It is planned out well.But I've got to be honest. I really didn't like any of it. I didn't like any of the characters. I found the plot random and stupid. The language grated on my nerves. It was so vulgar. All the females in this book are harpies or whores or idiots, except for Phoebe. And that makes me want to break something.  There was so much teenage angst. Oh, gosh. Holden is totally the black knight:   I totally feel like: This book was just very alien from my personality. I couldn't relate. I can empathize some, but not much. I don't like it. But I'm glad I read it. I'm going to go find something upbeat and happy now.Yours Momentary Devoid of Angst,Amy

“I think that one of these days," he said, "you're going to have to find out where you want to go. And then you've got to start going there. But immediately. You can't afford to lose a minute. Not you.”

I specifically bought this book to reread and write a review on, because the first time I read it I was 17/18 and didn’t have more than two brain cells.Aaand I write a review almost a month after reading it. I blame it on the absence of my laptop, but laziness had a role in this too.The main reason why people love this book is because we were all hypocritical dicks with emotional problems at one point in our life. Especially in our teen years. And especially at that time, we don’t have a clue what we want from life or who we are.
“I can’t explain what I mean. And even if I could, I’m not sure I’d feel like it.”
There isn’t much of anything going on in this book, it follows its main character, Holden Caulfield, and his thoughts.Holden is a character a person can easily dislike, he is judgemental, hypocritical, and confused. One that isn’t ready to transgress into the “phony” world of adults.The catcher in the rye depicts all of the conflicting inner thoughts and emotions of a person in their formative years (okay, not all people go through depression like Holden, but these are important years and a lot of people have the first signs of their mental illness back at that age; I had the issue of mild depression back then after the death of a family member).
If one were to objectively read the book, Holden isn’t an ideal lead character one should look up to. But then again, he wasn’t meant to be that, and in this way, Holden became more close to millions of people who had the chance to read this book than he would have been having he been a more morally good character.
Because we aren’t all entirely devoid of flaws. And because sometimes the problem lies within ourselves and not in others, hence self-reflection is one of the traits that an adult has and not a child. And I think now, at 22, I appreciate this book way more than I did when I was a teenager. But I am glad that I did read it in my teen years, and would recommend the book to both teens and adults because everyone should have a chance of meeting the one and only Holden Caulfield.-------------------------------------------------------------Why do I like this book more now than I did at 18? Either way, a pleasant surprise. Review to come.
